name.page: Re: NCML Handler / Libdap4 ( Join New aggregation / Changing variable name Issue )
name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
Aafaque,
My apologies for the top post, but the thread is getting quite long.
Here‚Äôs what I found, the issue does not appear to be a problem of aggregating four or more files - I can get the error below to trigger with just one file. The problem is the renaming of the band_1 variable after it has been built up during an aggregation. (I‚Äôm very glad you sent all the various tiff and ncml files - I‚Äôd have never figured this out w/o them.)
Here‚Äôs what _will_ work: If you use NCML to rename the Grid variable ‚Äòband_1‚Äô to ‚ÄòSRB‚Äô for each file you intend to aggregate, you can then aggregate on the Grid ‚ÄòSRB.‚Äô So, given:
edamame:tests jimg$ ls ../data/gdal/
LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml
LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif
LC08_CU_002010_20130418_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml
LC08_CU_002010_20130418_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif
LC08_CU_002010_20130425_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml
LC08_CU_002010_20130425_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif
LC08_CU_002010_20130504_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml
LC08_CU_002010_20130504_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif
Where the .ncml files rename ‚Äòband_1‚Äô to ‚ÄòSRB2‚Äô in each of the matching .tif files, the following NCML will work:
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
<netcdf title="Time based join for california_LC08_SRB2" xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<aggregation dimName="time" type="joinNew">
<variableAgg name="SRB2" />
<netcdf coordValue="4854" location="/data/gdal/LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4856" location="/data/gdal/LC08_CU_002010_20130418_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4863" location="/data/gdal/LC08_CU_002010_20130425_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4872" location="/data/gdal/LC08_CU_002010_20130504_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
</aggregation>
<variable name="time" type="double">
<attribute name="units" type="string">days since 2000-01-01 00:00</attribute>
</variable>
</netcdf>
And the resulting 3 dimensional Grid will be named SRB2.
And, if you can live with the Grid being named ‚Äòband_1,‚Äô you can aggregate the .tif files like this:
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<netcdf title="Time based join for california_LC08_SRB2" xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<aggregation dimName="time" type="joinNew">
<variableAgg name="band_1" />
<netcdf coordValue="4854" location="/data/gdal/LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif" />
<netcdf coordValue="4856" location="/data/gdal/LC08_CU_002010_20130418_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif" />
<netcdf coordValue="4863" location="/data/gdal/LC08_CU_002010_20130425_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif" />
<netcdf coordValue="4872" location="/data/gdal/LC08_CU_002010_20130504_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif" />
</aggregation>
<variable name="time" type="double">
<attribute name="units" type="string">days since 2000-01-01 00:00</attribute>
</variable>
<!-- variable name="SRB2" orgName="band_1" / -->
</netcdf>
(note that I commented out the 'variable name="SRB2" orgName=‚Äúband_1‚Äù‚Äô part).
But, if you add <variable name="SRB2" orgName=‚Äúband_1"/> back in, the aggregation will fail. It‚Äôs a bug, at least I think it is a bug, but I cannot promise a fix soon. I tried, as a work around, using NCML to change the name of the resulting 3d Grid, like this:
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<netcdf location="/data/ncml/gdal/h02v10_tiff_files.ncml" xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<variable name="SRB2" orgName="band_1" />
</netcdf>
But that does not work, again, that maybe a bug.
So for now: You can aggregate as many TIFF files as you want, but if you want to rename the variable that results from the aggregation, you must do so by renaming all of its components first, then combine those together.
I‚Äôm sorry this took so long to sort out and that the outcome is less than satisfactory. What you‚Äôre trying seems logically correct, but fails because the NCML implementation is applying the variable rename operation (<variable name="SRB2" orgName="band_1" />) to the DDS of the elements of the aggregation, and not the DDS that results from the previous operations (i.e., the DDS of the aggregation).
Here‚Äôs the actual error message from the ASSERT in the code:
[MST Thu Feb 15 10:56:17 2018 id: 34209][ncml] NCMLModule InternalError: [static void agg_util::AggregationUtil::transferArrayConstraints(libdap::Array *, const libdap::Array &, bool, bool, bool, const std::string &)]: ASSERTION FAILED: condition=( fromArrIt->name == toArrIt->name ) GAggregationUtil::transferArrayConstraints: Expected the dimensions to have the same name but they did not: 'easting', 'northing‚Äô.
This is not in the code you‚Äôre running - that might be an issue as well - because assertions are compiled out for production releases. I‚Äôll change that so we trap these conditions and produce a more informative error message.
Thanks,
James
- show quoted text -
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.page: Re: NCML Handler / Libdap4 ( Join New aggregation / Changing variable name Issue )
name.name: Schroeder (CTR), Bradley
name.body:
Hi James,
I may be missing something in what you're saying. But I believe what you are suggesting is the exact thing that we tried originally and get an error as soon as we try to aggregate more than 3 .ncml files. We created one .ncml file for each .tif file. The .ncml file just renamed band_1 to SRB2. We can aggregate 3 of those together, but as soon as we add in a 4th file, it fails. I might be missing something, so I'll paste in here the contents of our time aggregation .ncml file, and the contents for the first referenced rename .ncml file.
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<netcdf title="Time based join for california_LC08_SRB2" xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<aggregation dimName="time" type="joinNew">
<variableAgg name="SRB2" />
<netcdf coordValue="4854" location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4856" location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130418_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4863" location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130425_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4872" location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130504_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
</aggregation>
<variable name="time" type="double">
<attribute name="units" type="string">days since 2000-01-01 00:00</attribute>
</variable>
</netcdf>
Here is the contents of /LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif" xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<variable name="SRB2" orgName="band_1" />
</netcdf>
Is that what you are suggesting? Because this does not work for us. When we try to retrieve data through the OPeNDAP UI it returns a 200 code, but doesn't return any data. As soon as I comment out any one of the 4 .ncml files (i.e. LC08_CU_002010_20130418_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml ) from the time aggregation .ncml it works as expected and returns data.
Your second suggestion of leaving it named band_1 does work as far as aggregation, we are using that as a work around right now. But that is preventing us from our ultimate goal. This product has 11 bands all in separate files and all named band_1 in the GeoTIFF. Our ultimate goal is to rename each band_1 to a meaningful name like SRB1, and then do a union on all of those variables and display the product as 1 product instead of 11 products. Here is an example of a union ncml we are trying. This is from a different test, so the filenames and directories don't match the previous examples.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<netcdf xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<aggregation type="union">
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB1/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB2/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB3/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB4/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB5/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB6/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB7/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_LINEAGEQA/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_RADSATQA/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_PIXELQA/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRAEROSOLQA/h005v002.ncml"/>
</aggregation>
<attribute name="title" type="string" value="Simple union aggregation test"/>
</netcdf>
Brad

name.page: Re: NCML Handler / Libdap4 ( Join New aggregation / Changing variable name Issue )
name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Feb 15, 2018, at 17:24, Schroeder (CTR), Bradley <bradley.sc...@usgs.gov> wrote:
Hi James,
I may be missing something in what you're saying. But I believe what you are suggesting is the exact thing that we tried originally and get an error as soon as we try to aggregate more than 3 .ncml files. We created one .ncml file for each .tif file. The .ncml file just renamed band_1 to SRB2. We can aggregate 3 of those together, but as soon as we add in a 4th file, it fails. I might be missing something, so I'll paste in here the contents of our time aggregation .ncml file, and the contents for the first referenced rename .ncml file.
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<netcdf title="Time based join for california_LC08_SRB2" xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<aggregation dimName="time" type="joinNew">
<variableAgg name="SRB2" />
<netcdf coordValue="4854" location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4856" location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130418_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4863" location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130425_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
<netcdf coordValue="4872" location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130504_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml" />
</aggregation>
<variable name="time" type="double">
<attribute name="units" type="string">days since 2000-01-01 00:00</attribute>
</variable>
</netcdf>
Here is the contents of /LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD/california/h02v10/LC08_CU_002010_20130416_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.tif" xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<variable name="SRB2" orgName="band_1" />
</netcdf>
Is that what you are suggesting? Because this does not work for us. When we try to retrieve data through the OPeNDAP UI it returns a 200 code, but doesn't return any data. As soon as I comment out any one of the 4 .ncml files (i.e. LC08_CU_002010_20130418_20170727_C01_V01_SRB2.ncml ) from the time aggregation .ncml it works as expected and returns data.
Yes. Hmmm. It worked for me, although I have to admit, I was running on OSX and not Linux‚Ä¶
Your second suggestion of leaving it named band_1 does work as far as aggregation, we are using that as a work around right now. But that is preventing us from our ultimate goal. This product has 11 bands all in separate files and all named band_1 in the GeoTIFF. Our ultimate goal is to rename each band_1 to a meaningful name like SRB1, and then do a union on all of those variables and display the product as 1 product instead of 11 products. Here is an example of a union ncml we are trying. This is from a different test, so the filenames and directories don't match the previous examples.
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<netcdf xmlns="http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/namespaces/netcdf/ncml-2.2">
<aggregation type="union">
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB1/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB2/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB3/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB4/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB5/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB6/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRB7/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_LINEAGEQA/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_RADSATQA/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_PIXELQA/h005v002.ncml"/>
<netcdf location="LANDSAT_ARD_AGGREGATES/LANDSAT_ARD_SRAEROSOLQA/h005v002.ncml"/>
</aggregation>
<attribute name="title" type="string" value="Simple union aggregation test"/>
</netcdf>
OK, I will look into this some more.
James

name.page: Re: NCML Handler / Libdap4 ( Join New aggregation / Changing variable name Issue )
name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Apr 9, 2018, at 07:54, Friesz (CTR), Aaron <aaron.fr...@usgs.gov> wrote:
Hi James and Slav,
I wanted to follow up on this NCML Handler/Libdap4 issue. Has there been any movement on this activity? What's the status?
Aaron, et al.,
This is a complicated bug. We are continuing to work on it, but the renaming issue is looking like it‚Äôs a problem deep in the NcML processing software. What this means is that I still can‚Äôt give you an estimate on when we will fix it.
My understanding is there are two problems you‚Äôve found, both having to do with aggregating TIFF files:
1. If you rename variables in a tiff file using NCML, you can aggregate three of the resulting things, but not more than that.
2. You can aggregate 3, 4, ‚Ä¶, tiff files but then renaming the resulting variable does not work.
Slav, CC‚Äôd on this response is working on #1 and I will work on #2
James
- show quoted text -
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.page: Re: NCML Handler / Libdap4 ( Join New aggregation / Changing variable name Issue )
name.name: Schroeder (CTR), Bradley
name.body:
Hi James,
Yes, that is the issue.
One question we had. In a previous email it sounded like you are able to get #1 to work on your OSX machine. Is it possible that you have some updated code that we don't have running hyrax 1.14.0?
Thanks,
Brad

name.page: Re: NCML Handler / Libdap4 ( Join New aggregation / Changing variable name Issue )
name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Apr 9, 2018, at 15:02, Schroeder (CTR), Bradley <bradley.sc...@usgs.gov> wrote:
Hi James,
Yes, that is the issue.
One question we had. In a previous email it sounded like you are able to get #1 to work on your OSX machine. Is it possible that you have some updated code that we don't have running hyrax 1.14.0?
Possible, but more likely I was confused. These are really two very different problems and, I suspect, have nothing to do with TIFF. When you posed the problem initially, I was sure I knew exactly where the issue was and that it was part of an error in the TIFF processing module, but I was wrong.
James
- show quoted text -
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Stefan,
Would you please share with me a narrative regarding how you came to experience the error?
When I looked at your subset URL it appears you have copied and pasted it from the HTML Data Request Form here:
http://acdisc.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/HDF-EOS5/ncml/Aura_OMI_Level3/OMAEROe.003/2004/OMI-Aura_L3-OMAEROe_2004m1001_v003-2011m1109t080411.he5.ncml.html
Which I think is a mistake, in that you cannot use the URL as it appears in the text field without some modification.
For example, if you push the ‚ÄúGet ASCII‚Äù button on the form page the URL is altered by appending a suffix of ‚Äú.ascii‚Äù to the request URL path, the part before the question mark.
Here‚Äôs another example that returns just the DDS metadata response. I took your request URL and appended ‚Äú.dds‚Äù to the URL path:
http://acdisc.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/HDF-EOS5/ncml/Aura_OMI_Level3/OMAEROe.003/2004/OMI-Aura_L3-OMAEROe_2004m1001_v003-2011m1109t080411.he5.ncml.dds?AbsorbingAerosolOpticalThicknessMW[0:4][0:719][0:1439],AerosolModelMW[0:719][0:1439],AerosolOpticalThicknessMW[0:4][0:719][0:1439],AerosolOpticalThicknessPassedThresholdMean[0:719][0:1439],AerosolOpticalThicknessPassedThresholdStd[0:719][0:1439],SingleScatteringAlbedoMW[0:4][0:719][0:1439],SingleScatteringAlbedoPassedThresholdMean[0:719][0:1439],SingleScatteringAlbedoPassedThresholdStd[0:719][0:1439],SolarZenithAngle[0:719][0:1439],TerrainReflectivity[0:719][0:1439],UVAerosolIndex[0:719][0:1439],VISAerosolIndex[0:719][0:1439],ViewingZenithAngle[0:719][0:1439],nWavelDiagnostic,lat[0:719],lon[0:1439]
NOTE: Your emailer is likely to botch this link by dropping the closing ‚Äú]‚Äù from the link - you will need to copy and paste it into a browser‚Äôs address bar or into a curl command to make it work:
curl -g -k -n -c ursCookies -b ursCookies -L --url http://acdisc.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/HDF-EOS5/ncml/Aura_OMI_Level3/OMAEROe.003/2004/OMI-Aura_L3-OMAEROe_2004m1001_v003-2011m1109t080411.he5.ncml.dds?AbsorbingAerosolOpticalThicknessMW[0:4][0:719][0:1439],AerosolModelMW[0:719][0:1439],AerosolOpticalThicknessMW[0:4][0:719][0:1439],AerosolOpticalThicknessPassedThresholdMean[0:719][0:1439],AerosolOpticalThicknessPassedThresholdStd[0:719][0:1439],SingleScatteringAlbedoMW[0:4][0:719][0:1439],SingleScatteringAlbedoPassedThresholdMean[0:719][0:1439],SingleScatteringAlbedoPassedThresholdStd[0:719][0:1439],SolarZenithAngle[0:719][0:1439],TerrainReflectivity[0:719][0:1439],UVAerosolIndex[0:719][0:1439],VISAerosolIndex[0:719][0:1439],ViewingZenithAngle[0:719][0:1439],nWavelDiagnostic,lat[0:719],lon[0:1439]
If by chance you are planning on using curl to retrieve data you should read the instructions for making it work with NASA‚Äôs Earthdata Login (aka URS) service here:
https://opendap.github.io/hyrax_guide/Master_Hyrax_Guide.html#_authentication_for_dap_clients
You may also request data in a number of response encodings by utilizing other suffix expressions on the URL path:
DAP2: ‚Äú.dods‚Äù
DAP4: ‚Äú.dap"
NetCDF-3: ‚Äú.nc‚Äù
NetCDF-4: ‚Äú.nc4‚Äù

name.page: PyDAP Access broken after HyRAX upgrade
name.name: Matt Ueckermann
name.body:
HI Folks,
I‚Äôve been badgering the excellent people at NSIDC (see below) about OpenDAP access using PyDAP. My problem is described here: https://github.com/pydap/pydap/issues/163 with additional details below.
Essentially it seems like there‚Äôs been a string parsing or escaping issue after 1.13.1. As part of the metadata, a greater-than sign is no longer decoded ‚Äì and since the html encoding contains a semi-colon, the ‚Äòdas‚Äô file is not correctly interpreted.
Hyrax 1.14.0:
(<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
Hyrax 1.13.5:
(<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
Previous Hyrax version (1.13.1):
<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
The same thing seems to happen in decoding the keys use for the dataset. Copied from below:
For example, I used to access longitude using the key:
o ‚ÄòSoil_Moisture_Retrieval_Data_1km_longitude_1km‚Äô
¬∑ but now it is
o ‚Äò%2FSoil_Moisture_Retrieval_Data_1km%2Flongitude_1km‚Äô
Here the forward slash ‚Äú/‚Äù is not escaped and the %2F remains.
Please let me know if this is a bug, or if it‚Äôs new / expected behavior. If the latter, I need to work with the pydap folks for a work-around.
Thanks very much,
Matt
From: National Snow & Ice Data Center [mailto:ns...@nsidc.org]
Sent: Monday, March 19, 2018 7:31 AM
To: Matt Ueckermann
Subject: [National Snow & Ice Data Center] Re: openDap access

Matt Ueckermann, Mar 19, 05:30 MDT:
Hi Amy,
I will contact the OpenDAP folks as well.
In the mean time, my eds = ‚Ä¶ line of code is somewhat complicated, but I‚Äôve copied it below.
Best,
Matt
=====================================================================================================================
import requests
class SessionWithHeaderRedirection(requests.Session):
"""
Modified from: https://wiki.earthdata.nasa.gov/display/EL/How+To+Access+Data+With+Python
"""
AUTH_HOST = ''
def __init__(self, username=None, password=None):
super(SessionWithHeaderRedirection, self).__init__()
self.auth = (username, password)
# Overrides from the library to keep headers when redirected to or from
# the NASA auth host.
def rebuild_auth(self, prepared_request, response):
headers = prepared_request.headers
url = prepared_request.url
if 'Authorization' in headers:
original_parsed = requests.utils.urlparse(response.request.url)
redirect_parsed = requests.utils.urlparse(url)
if (original_parsed.hostname != redirect_parsed.hostname) and \
redirect_parsed.hostname != self.AUTH_HOST and \
original_parsed.hostname != self.AUTH_HOST:
del headers['Authorization']
return
class EarthDataSession(SessionWithHeaderRedirection):
AUTH_HOST = 'urs.earthdata.nasa.gov'
eds = EarthDataSession (username=<My EarthDataLogin Username>, password=<My EarthDataLogin Password>)
# Test url: used to generate cookies for session
eds.get("https://n5eil01u.ecs.nsidc.org:443/opendap/SMAP/SPL3SMP.004/2015.04.06/SMAP_L3_SM_P_20150406_R14010_001.h5.dds")
=====================================================================================================================

Matt Ueckermann, Feb 12, 09:10 MST:
Greetings,
* Has NSIDC recently changed the meta-data served through the OpenDAP protocol?
* If yes, is there any way to remove errant semi-colons that are in the metadata?
I've been accessing SMAP datasources using the OpenDAP protocol with pydap (through Python).
Recently (noticed this Friday), I have been unable to so because of an error parsing the metadata in the .das file (which is part of OpenDAP). I've posted an issue on the pydap github page here with the technical details: https://github.com/pydap/pydap/issues/163
The problematic section of the metadata is as follows:
<gmd:organisationName>
<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
</gmd:organisationName>
Essentially, the organization name has an errant semi-colon which looks a lot like escaped html, but the .das format uses semi-colons to separate different fields. As such, pydap does not successfully parse the metadata and fails ungracefully.
I'm not sure if the problem is with pydap, or with the metadata from NSIDC -- i.e. whether the errant semi-colon follows or breaks the .das fileformat spec.
Any help much appreciated,
Matt
------------------
Submitted from: https://nsidc.org/
You can add a comment by replying to this email.
This email is a service from National Snow & Ice Data Center.
[Z39R9X-76G2]

name.page: PyDAP Access broken after HyRAX upgrade
name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Mar 19, 2018, at 05:50, Matt Ueckermann <m...@creare.com> wrote:
HI Folks,
I‚Äôve been badgering the excellent people at NSIDC (see below) about OpenDAP access using PyDAP. My problem is described here: https://github.com/pydap/pydap/issues/163 with additional details below.
Essentially it seems like there‚Äôs been a string parsing or escaping issue after 1.13.1. As part of the metadata, a greater-than sign is no longer decoded ‚Äì and since the html encoding contains a semi-colon, the ‚Äòdas‚Äô file is not correctly interpreted.
Hyrax 1.14.0:
(<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
Hyrax 1.13.5:
(<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
Matt,
The response above, with the > is actually correct XML. It‚Äôs a pain because the XML and DAS syntaxes are fighting here, since the ; in a value has to be escaped either with a backslash or by enclosing it in double quotes. Luckily, the latter _is_ the case, so a simple modification to the DAS parser should fix this problem. I hope the PyDAP developers can help you with that.
That is, for a DAS attribute value that is a String, the characters between double quotes should not be evaluated except that embedded double quotes should be escaped (and that‚Äôs the case with these servers‚Äô values).
This next question is a bit harder...
Previous Hyrax version (1.13.1):
<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
The same thing seems to happen in decoding the keys use for the dataset. Copied from below:
For example, I used to access longitude using the key:
o ‚ÄòSoil_Moisture_Retrieval_Data_1km_longitude_1km‚Äô
¬∑ but now it is
o ‚Äò%2FSoil_Moisture_Retrieval_Data_1km%2Flongitude_1km‚Äô
Here the forward slash ‚Äú/‚Äù is not escaped and the %2F remains.
Please let me know if this is a bug, or if it‚Äôs new / expected behavior. If the latter, I need to work with the pydap folks for a work-around.
This is a new behavior. Working with The HDF Group, we‚Äôve been trying to sort out how to represent HDF5 Groups in DAP2 and decided on using slash characters. Of course, that‚Äôs not a great syntax for the web, so the slash is escaped. The old technique was to represent slash as an underscore, but that meant that the names were hard to recover in some cases.
Thus, this is the new expected behavior.
Sorry for the hassles this causes. If you would like me to talk to the PyDAP developers, feel free to ask.
James
Thanks very much,
Matt
From: National Snow & Ice Data Center [mailto...@nsidc.org]
- show quoted text -
- show quoted text -
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

> Matt Ueckermann, Feb 12, 09:10 MST:
> Greetings,
> * Has NSIDC recently changed the meta-data served through the OpenDAP protocol?
> * If yes, is there any way to remove errant semi-colons that are in the metadata?
> I've been accessing SMAP datasources using the OpenDAP protocol with pydap (through Python).
> Recently (noticed this Friday), I have been unable to so because of an error parsing the metadata in the .das file (which is part of OpenDAP). I've posted an issue on the pydap github page here with the technical details: https://github.com/pydap/pydap/issues/163
> The problematic section of the metadata is as follows:
> <gmd:organisationName>
> <gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
> </gmd:organisationName>
> Essentially, the organization name has an errant semi-colon which looks a lot like escaped html, but the .das format uses semi-colons to separate different fields. As such, pydap does not successfully parse the metadata and fails ungracefully.
> I'm not sure if the problem is with pydap, or with the metadata from NSIDC -- i.e. whether the errant semi-colon follows or breaks the .das fileformat spec.
> Any help much appreciated,
> Matt

name.name: Matt Ueckermann
name.body:
As far as I can tell, d.quotes are NOT escaped‚Ä¶ at least by the time pydap gets a hold of them in python.
From here:
https://n5eil01u.ecs.nsidc.org/opendap/SMAP/SPL3SMP.004/2015.04.06/SMAP_L3_SM_P_20150406_R14010_001.h5.das
A small excerpt:
String iso_19139_dataset_xml "<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no" ?>
<gmd:DS_Series xmlns:gmd="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gmd" xmlns="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gmi" xmlns:eos="http://earthdata.nasa.gov/schema/eos" xmlns:gco="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gco" xmlns:gmi="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gmi" xmlns:gml="http://www.opengis.net/gml/3.2" xmlns:gmx="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gmx" xmlns:gsr="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gsr" xmlns:gss="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gss" xmlns:gts="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gts" xmlns:srv="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/srv" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" xmlns:xs="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.isotc211.org/2005/gmi http://cdn.earthdata.nasa.gov/iso/schema/1.0/ISO19115-2_EOS.xsd">
‚Ä¶
After this line https://github.com/pydap/pydap/blob/release/3.2.1/src/pydap/handlers/dap.py#L61, I have unescaped d.quotes in the python string.
I‚Äôm now using the following regex, and that *seems* to do the trick: ".*?[^\\]"[,;] but it could fail in some instances as well.
Still testing‚Ä¶
Matt

Sent: Monday, March 19, 2018 3:51 PM

name.page: PyDAP Access broken after HyRAX upgrade
name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Kent,
(I am including Mark and Matt because they are stakeholders in this issue.)
Your explanation helped a lot.
I went to test.opendap.org and configured it with:
H5.EnableCF=true
H5.EnableDropLongString=false
http://test.opendap.org/opendap/NSIDC/SMAP_L3_SM_P_20150406_R14010_001.h5.das
This exposed BOTH the top level attributes:
iso_19139_dataset_xml
iso_19139_series_xml
And while now all of the double quotes are correctly escaped the greater-than-sign character is encoded differently in the two attributes:
iso_19139_dataset_xml:
<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
iso_19139_series_xml:
<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
And I think that Ken is correct, the iso_19139_dataset_xml encoding is borking the PyDAP DAS parser.
So if NSIDC sees value in publishing the iso_19139_dataset_xml attribute then something needs to change, either the PyDAP DAS parser or the source file content. I think one can make a case for both changes:
- The DAS parser should be lenient w.r.t String valued attribute content and pretty much just slurp up everything between the un-escaped double quotes.
- The source data file should NOT be double encoding the embedded XML document content (> is correct, &gt; is not correct)
Does this make sense to everyone? Matt, Mark, & James may want to read the thread below to catch up, but I think this summary has all of the salient points.
Sorry for all the confusion, but I think this is a better statement of the issue than previously.
Sincerely,
Nathan
> On Mar 20, 2018, at 7:01 AM, Kent Yang <mya...@hdfgroup.org> wrote:
>
> Hi Nathan,
>
> Don't blame yourself. It is easy to get confused. This is the issue from this SMAP file. See if my explanation makes sense to you. If not, we may set up a phone conversation to get this clear. My phone is 217-531-6107. I am at my office 9 am to 12pm and 1 pm to 5 pm Central time.
>
> There are two attributes in this file:
> iso_19139_dataset_xml
> iso_19139_series_xml
>
> Inside iso_19139_series_xml, you have
> <gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
>
> Inside iso_19139_dataset_xml, you have
> <gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
>
> Notice the &amp above: I think that causes an issue with pydap.
>
> When EnableCF=false, the handler tries to match everything in this SMAP to DAP2 regardless of any Conventions users preferred. So both attributes are mapped to DAP2.
> When EnableCF=true, the handler will customize the mapping to follow the CF and please popular client(netCDFjava etc.). So for this version, iso_19139_dataset_xml is ignored.
>
> What you see that the attribute is changed to a different name is actually the attribute iso_19139_series_xml. The attribute name is not changed. This is just another attribute. The attribute that causes pydap choken is simply ignored.
>
> This can be verified from the attached ncdump header.
>
> As for the issue pydap faces, I think the user should contact NSIDC to report the issue inside the HDF5 file itself rather than asking us to hack the DAP2 or the handler to make his problem go away.
>
> Kent
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Nathan Potter [mailto:n...@opendap.org]
> Sent: Monday, March 19, 2018 8:59 PM
> To: Kent Yang
> Cc: n...@opendap.org
> Subject: Re: [support] PyDAP Access broken after HyRAX upgrade
>
>
>
>> On Mar 19, 2018, at 6:19 PM, Kent Yang <mya...@hdfgroup.org> wrote:
>>
>> Nathan.
>>
>> I fully understand what you said. However, I don't see
>> iso_19139_dataset_xml attribute in this https://n5eil01u.ecs.nsidc.org/opendap/SMAP/SPL3SMP.004/2015.04.06/SMAP_L3_SM_P_20150406_R14010_001.h5.das .
>>
>> That's why I don't think he made H5.EnableDropLongString=false in his configuration. So we cannot be sure whether the issue is resolved.
>>
>> Am I checking the correct URL?
>
> You are, and to be honest I am pretty damn confused. Basically when the server was EnableCF=false we saw this messed up attribute value for ‚Äúiso_19139_dataset_xml‚Äù which was an XML document with incorrectly escaped double quotes.
>
> Now, with EnableCF=true, the XML document appears to be associated with an attribute of a different name, and it‚Äôs double quotes are correctly escaped.
>
> You can download the dataset from the NSIDC site or from test.opendap.org:
>
> http://test.opendap.org/opendap/NSIDC/SMAP_L3_SM_P_20150406_R14010_001.h5
>
> Sorry, I just don‚Äôt understand.
>
> Nathan
>
>
>>
>> Kent
>>
>>
>> On Mar 19, 2018, at 5:53 PM, Nathan Potter <n...@opendap.org> wrote:
>>
>>> Kent,
>>>
>>> I think we are talking about two different issues.
>>>
>>> When he changed the config to: H5.EnableCF=true then his output, here:
>>>
>>> https://n5eil01u.ecs.nsidc.org/opendap/SMAP/SPL3SMP.004/2015.04.06/SM
>>> AP_L3_SM_P_20150406_R14010_001.h5.das
>>>
>>> Looks correct in that the double quote characters in the ‚Äúiso_19139_dataset_xml‚Äù attribute are now correctly escaped.
>>>
>>> Which is what I was trying to understand. And the attribute is still in the dataset DAS so I am thinking the he already has H5.EnableDropLongString=false in his config.
>>>
>>> Does that make sense?
>>>
>>>
>>> Nathan
>>>
>>>
>>>> On Mar 19, 2018, at 2:34 PM, Kent Yang <mya...@hdfgroup.org> wrote:
>>>>
>>>> Nathan,
>>>>
>>>> Actually this is not quite right.
>>>> The NSIDC should change
>>>> H5.EnableDropLongString=true
>>>> to
>>>> H5.EnableDropLongString=false
>>>>
>>>> The current das output ignores attribute iso_19139_dataset_xml. The disappearance of double quote is because the attribute is turned off.
>>>> As in the email I forwarded to you, if there are any issues in the double quotes in the CF option, we can check that. In my last investigation, the issue comes from the HDF5 itself, not in the Hyrax layer.
>>>> I may be wrong but I need to be fed more information. Do you guys have a ticket related to this?
>>>>
>>>> Kent

name.page: PyDAP Access broken after HyRAX upgrade
name.name: Kent Yang
name.body:
Nathan,
I agree with your statement.
One add-on for this thread. Because of this issue, I improved the handler to support the long string attribute like this iso_19139_dataset.xml in the CF option. This is because the current netCDF java can accept this case rather than throwing an error. So In the next Hyrax release, NSIDC folks won't see the drop of long string in their SMAP service. This may easily make the issue related to the SMAP file itself out of the surface.
Kent

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Matt,
So I heard from Mark @NSIDC and now there server is correctly escaping the double quote, but the change in content to replace the offending &gt; with > is only something he can suggest to the team that encodes the metadata.
https://n5eil01u.ecs.nsidc.org/opendap/SMAP/SPL3SMP.004/2015.04.06/SMAP_L3_SM_P_20150406_R14010_001.h5.das
I think the upshot is that James' suggestion to make the PyDAP DAS parser smarter is the right thing to do, and now that double quotes are correctly escaped within the string valued attributes it should be possible.
We can help communicating with the PyDAP team if needed.
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Freddy,
This is in fact a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù error.
You are attempting to access a dataset that requires you to be authenticated in order to get data access (thus the 401 response)
All NASA datasets require data access requests to be authenticated using their Earthdata Login system.
You can read how to enable Matlab to do this here:
https://opendap.github.io/hyrax_guide/Master_Hyrax_Guide.html#_authentication_for_dap_clients
Sections "6.3.2. Earthdata Login Users" and "6.3.9 Matlab, Ferret, Other applications that use NetCDF C‚Äù should help you get it sorted out.
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Amitava,
That server will return an ASCII response (which is not exactly CSV - but it‚Äôs close) and a JSON response. These are not very efficient transfer encodings and the individual variables u, v, um, and vm each have 41 million values, not counting their associated map vectors. I mention this because it suggests that unless your area of interest is the entire globe you will want to subset the data to just your area of interest. Subsetting is accomplished using the array indices of the variables and NOT by using the associated values. If you need help with that I can assist.
For now lets look at the encodings and computational issues.
You can see the overall structure of the data set by examining the DDS response, note the suffix I have added to the dataset URL:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel1993.nc.gz.dds
To keep the results manageable I will request just the latitude array.
Here is a request for the latitude array as an ASCII response. Please, note the change of suffix and the addition of a query string that names the requested variable, latitude:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel1993.nc.gz.ascii?latitude
To get the same data as JSON simply change the suffix to ‚Äú.json":
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel1993.nc.gz.json?latitude
With regards to the computational question: There are metadata embedded in the dataset that provide a number of insights into the variables and the dataset in general. You can view the complete metadata response by changing the URL suffix to ‚Äú.das‚Äù:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel1993.nc.gz.das
There you can see the units of each variable and also find contact information for the people that generated the dataset. I suggest that you contact them with your computational questions (We at OPeNDAP only provide the data access service software and we do not produce the data served.)
However your basic question: ‚ÄúHow to calculate the resultant ocean current and direction from the raw data?‚Äù Would seem to me to be a matter of combining the values of u and v to produce a current vector with direction and magnitude at each physical location. If you need more guidance you should definitely write the authors referenced in the dataset metadata.
Sincerely,
Nathan
- show quoted text -

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Jay,
First please understand that OPeNDAP is in no way involved with the production or analysis of the data. We provide the server software. Your questions about calculations should be directed to the publisher/authors listed in the metadata.
You might consider reading the documentation provided on the site. In the catalog directory for the data you are working with:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/
There is a ‚Äúdocs‚Äù directory link:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/docs/
Which contains a PDF file that you should probably read as it discusses, in detail, the file naming conventions, the data organization, and the calculations used in the production of the data.
I will provide other answers inline below.
> On Mar 9, 2018, at 9:55 AM, JAYARAMAN IYER <jayar...@yahoo.com> wrote:
>
> Hi Nathan,
>
> Thanks for providing the details to Amitava, who had forwarded the same to me.
>
> I am looking for Ocean Surface currents as at specific locations as on a specific time
> (these will correspond to location of a few ships for which we will be analyzing using this data.)
>
> I am not much aware of how this data is organized. Will be helpful to us if you could further clarify on these or point us the direction.
>
> 1) The dataset url used was https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel9284.nc.gz.json
>
>
> I understand that the data corresponds to "Mar.07,2018".
>
> How will the url be for getting data as on any other date of 2017 or 2018? Can we get the url based on the date?
Read the documentation I referenced above!
You have to figure that out from the catalog.
- Note that the units of time (in the metadata) are "day since 1992-10-05 00:00:00‚Äù
- Note that each dataset in the catalog https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg appears to have single time point (I have not checked them all)
- Note that the dataset you referenced at https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel9284.nc.gz has a single time value of 9284, which is the number of days since October 5th 1992 and that value appears in the file name
I believe that this is enough information for you to sort it out from there.
>
> 2) Are there consolidated datasets available organized with full year data?
Well, there appear to be some 1 degree data with annual files here:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/hyrax/allData/oscar/L4/oscar_1_deg/contents.html
Along with documentation and software for IDL and MatLab to assist in working with the data.
>
> 3) Is it possible to get the data for a specific location?
>
> I tried filtering by specifying the same in url like:
> https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel9284.nc.gz.json?Latitude=21&Longitude=21
>
> That did not return results but gave error: No such identifier in dataset:
The response was correct, you made several mistakes.
- The variable names are case sensitive. It is not Latitude, but latitude. It is not Longitude, but longitude. The capitalization and spelling must match what you see in the DDS response precisely: https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel9284.nc.gz.dds
- You CANNOT subset using values. You MUST subset using the array index of the thing you want.
- The subset syntax you used is not supported.
This URL:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/oscar/preview/L4/oscar_third_deg/oscar_vel9284.nc.gz.ascii?latitude[21],longitude[21]
Returns the 22nd value of the latitude array and the 22nd value of the longitude array (array indexes begin at zero)
If you have an area of interest you can determine the indices by examining the map vectors (there are 4 in this dataset but time and depth have only a single index so they are trivial) and then determining the index bounds of the area you wish to retrieve. Alternately, since in this dataset the latitude and longitude vectors appear to be regularly space, you could compute the index from a value by making a simple math problem. Please notice that the metadata says clearly:
"Longitude extends from 20 E to 420 E to avoid a break in major ocean basins. Data repeats in overlap region."
So be careful with that.
In the end you will have a constraint that resembles this:
?u[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961]
Where 220 is the index of the maximum latitude value and 260 is the index of the minimum latitude value (Note that latitude is decreasing)
and 881 is the index of the minimum longitude value and 961 is the index of the maximum longitude value.
Obviously these indices won‚Äôt work for you unless I have some how read your mind, but hopefully this illustrates the idea.
You can ask for all 4 variables like this (using the same constraint):
datasetURL.json?u[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961],v[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961],um[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961],vm[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961]
Or one at a time:
datasetURL.json?u[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961]
datasetURL.json?v[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961]
datasetURL.json?um[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961]
datasetURL.json?vm[0][0][220:1:260][881:1:961]
>
> 4) Using the four values of a point u, v, um, vm:
>
> We compute the resultant vector magnitude (in m/s) as sqrt(u ^2 + v ^2) and direction (in degrees) as atan(vm / um)
>
> Are these calculations correct? (I used this based on general understanding of vector calculations)
I would be guessing. Read the documentation I referenced above...
>
> 5) Are there any premium subscriptions available with you which can get us filtered data?
>
> Will be very helpful if you could help on the above.
What do you mean ‚Äúfiltered data‚Äù?
This data is published by NASA‚Äôs Jet Propulsion Laboratory and as far as I know there are no ‚Äúpremium subscriptions‚Äù
Cheers,
Nathan
>
>
> Thanks & regards,
> Jay
>
>

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Jay,
Here‚Äôs a more detailed answer I provided to another user recently. You‚Äôll need to adjust the details to fit your target data circumstance, but I think it‚Äôs a relevant template for determining the indices of your subset:
> The server software only subsets by array index, not by value.
>
> You have to do a little work to associate the value range that you desire with the appropriate indices.
>
> First, look at the sizes of the things in question. This URL will return a formatted description of the structure of the dataset:
>
> https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.dds
>
> You can easily view the values of the map variables in ascii by selecting just the variable name and specifying the type of responses (ascii) by appending that to the URL like so:
>
> https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.ascii?lat
> https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.ascii?lon
> https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.ascii?time
>
> From this you should be able to find the indices for each map variable that correspond to the desired value range.
>
> Since the values of lat and lon are regular you can calculate the indices from them.
>
> First express the value in terms of the index:
>
> lat_value = -1*(index - 900)/10;
>
> The -1 multiplier is because the values are decreasing, not increasing. The 900 is because that is the location of the lat value of 0, more or less.
>
> Solving for index:
>
> index = -1*lat_value*10 + 900;
>
> For the lower bound and upper bounds you want to push the index out by 1 index in the appropriate direction to make sure you get all the values that what you want:
>
> lat_index_min = -1*lat_value_min*10 + 900 + 1;
> lat_index_max = -1*lat_value_min*10 + 900 - 1;
>
> For your stated area of interest in latitude:
>
> lat_index_min = -1*25*10 + 900 + 1;
> lat_index_max = -1*40*10 + 900 - 1;
>
> lat_index_min = 651;
> lat_index_max = 499;
>
> And the numbers are ‚Äúreversed" because the data is decreasing in value by index.
>
> So your constraint for latitude should be roughly:
>
> lat[499:1:651]
>
> You can test each set of indices by requesting just the map values in the index expression added to the map variable name:
>
> https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.ascii?lat[499:1:651]
>
> You can do something quite similar for longitude, which I will leave as an exercise for you to complete.
>
Hopefully this wil provide some additional clarity.
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.name: Ali Fallah
name.body:
Dear support‚Äôs team,
I would like to download MSWEP V2.1 precipitation data with 0.1-degree resolution over Iran (Time: month (total data) Lat: 25-40 degree lon: 42-63 degree).
I was wondering if you help me how it would be possible to download data in 0.1o resolution in NetCDF4? I‚Äôve entered variables like this:
Time: 0:1:455
Lat: 25:1:40
Lon: 42:1:63
However, it seems, data downloads in 1-degree resolution!
I have another problem! When I would like to download such a data for all of the earth and enter time, lat and lon by default, there is a Hyrax Error ‚Äì Internal Error (500)!
https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.nc4?precipitation[0:1:455][0:1:1799][0:1:3599]
I‚Äôm looking forward to your reply.
Regards,
Ali Fallah
‚Äã

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Ali,
The server software only subsets by array index, not by value.
You have to do a little work to associate the value range that you desire with the appropriate indices.
First, look at the sizes of the things in question. This URL will return a formatted description of the structure of the dataset:
https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.dds
You can easily view the values of the map variables in ascii by selecting just the variable name and specifying the type of responses (ascii) by appending that to the URL like so:
https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.ascii?lat
https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.ascii?lon
https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.ascii?time
From this you should be able to find the indices for each map variable that correspond to the desired value range.
Since the values of lat and lon are regular you can calculate the indices from them.
First express the value in terms of the index:
lat_value = -1*(index - 900)/10;
The -1 multiplier is because the values are decreasing, not increasing. The 900 is because that is the location of the lat value of 0, more or less.
Solving for index:
index = -1*lat_value*10 + 900;
For the lower bound and upper bounds you want to push the index out by 1 index in the appropriate direction to make sure you get all the values that what you want:
lat_index_min = -1*lat_value_min*10 + 900 + 1;
lat_index_max = -1*lat_value_min*10 + 900 - 1;
For your stated area of interest in latitude:
lat_index_min = -1*25*10 + 900 + 1;
lat_index_max = -1*40*10 + 900 - 1;
lat_index_min = 651;
lat_index_max = 499;
And the numbers are ‚Äúreversed" because the data is decreasing in value by index.
So your constraint for latitude should be roughly:
lat[499:1:651]
You can test each set of indices by requesting just the map values in the index expression added to the map variable name:
https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap/MSWEP_V2.1/global_monthly_010deg.nc.ascii?lat[499:1:651]
You can do something quite similar for longitude, which I will leave as an exercise for you to complete.
Let me know if you have questions.
Sincerely,
Nathan
- show quoted text -
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: prince...@gmail.com
name.body:
Dear Nathan Potter,
Thank you for registering. The MSWEP data are available for download via https://data.princetonclimate.com/opendap. Please use the following login information:
User ID: NathanPotter963
Password: 2YU27F0YKRDRc44
Please keep in mind that the accuracy of the dataset is significantly better from 2000 onwards. Furthermore, when comparing gridded precipitation datasets with daily gauge observations, it is recommended to compute daily accumulations for all gridded datasets for the 24-hour period ending at the specific reporting time of the gauge. This is essential to avoid temporal mismatches between time series based on the gridded datasets and the observations. The MSWEP V2 technical documentation (available via www.gloh2o.org) provides reporting times for the GHCN-D and GSOD gauges.
Please cite the following paper when using MSWEP in any publication:
Beck, H.E., A.I.J.M. van Dijk, V. Levizzani, J. Schellekens, D.G. Miralles, B. Martens, A. de Roo: MSWEP: 3-hourly 0.25 global gridded precipitation (1979-2015) by merging gauge, satellite, and reanalysis data, Hydrology and Earth System Sciences, 21(1), 589-615, 2017.
The MSWEP V2 paper is currently in preparation. The methodology for V2 is described in the technical documentation (available via www.gloh2o.org). Note that MSWEP V1 and V2 and many other precipitation datasets have been evaluated in the following paper:
Beck, H. E., Vergopolan, N., Pan, M., Levizzani, V., van Dijk, A. I. J. M., Weedon, G. P., Brocca, L., Pappenberger, F., Huffman, G. J., and Wood, E. F.: Global-scale evaluation of 22 precipitation datasets using gauge observations and hydrological modeling, Hydrol. Earth Syst. Sci., 21, 6201-6217, 2017.
Please let me know if you have questions.
Regards,
Hylke Beck
www.gloh2o.org

I am working with CMIP5 data for my PhD project. I am trying to subset required GCM data using OpenDAP acess form. however, i need data in NetCDF formate but the form gives only options for GET ASCII or Get Binary.

Thanking you for inanticipation and best regards
Saleem

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Saleem,
I think that if all you want to do is to download the netcdf file you can simply alter the URL like this:
Your original DAP Access URL:
https://esgf.nci.org.au/thredds/dodsC/cmip5/output1/CSIRO-BOM/ACCESS1-0/historical/mon/atmos/Amon/r1i1p1/v20120727/zg/zg_Amon_ACCESS1-0_historical_r1i1p1_190001-194912.nc
HTTP File Service URL:
https://esgf.nci.org.au/thredds/fileServer/cmip5/output1/CSIRO-BOM/ACCESS1-0/historical/mon/atmos/Amon/r1i1p1/v20120727/zg/zg_Amon_ACCESS1-0_historical_r1i1p1_190001-194912.nc
But the file is large (more than 1GB) and you may wish to subset it. In order to do that you can use the DAP URL with a query string. Here is an example (that returns the structural/syntactic metadata and not the numeric values) of the dataset with a subset expression that asks for the 100th time slice of the Grid variable ‚Äúzg‚Äù:
https://esgf.nci.org.au/thredds/dodsC/cmip5/output1/CSIRO-BOM/ACCESS1-0/historical/mon/atmos/Amon/r1i1p1/v20120727/zg/zg_Amon_ACCESS1-0_historical_r1i1p1_190001-194912.nc.dds?zg[99:1:99][0:1:16][0:1:143][0:1:191]
To get the data response back as a netcdf file you can use the NetCDF command line tools command ‚Äúnccopy‚Äù like this (Please observe the minor but crucial change in the URL path where the ‚Äú.dds‚Äù suffix has been removed from the previous URL):
nccopy "https://esgf.nci.org.au/thredds/dodsC/cmip5/output1/CSIRO-BOM/ACCESS1-0/historical/mon/atmos/Amon/r1i1p1/v20120727/zg/zg_Amon_ACCESS1-0_historical_r1i1p1_190001-194912.nc?zg[99:1:99][0:1:16][0:1:143][0:1:191]‚Äù localFileName.nc
The NetCDF command used here is part of the NetCDF library which you can get from: https://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/netcdf/
Using the query string can greatly reduce the amount of data transferred by allowing you to subset the dataset to retrieve just the times and area of interest. The subsetting is accomplished using the array index values and NOT the actual data values. You can use the ascii data response to examine the Map variables to determine which array indices are appropriate for your area of interest:
https://esgf.nci.org.au/thredds/dodsC/cmip5/output1/CSIRO-BOM/ACCESS1-0/historical/mon/atmos/Amon/r1i1p1/v20120727/zg/zg_Amon_ACCESS1-0_historical_r1i1p1_190001-194912.nc.ascii?time
https://esgf.nci.org.au/thredds/dodsC/cmip5/output1/CSIRO-BOM/ACCESS1-0/historical/mon/atmos/Amon/r1i1p1/v20120727/zg/zg_Amon_ACCESS1-0_historical_r1i1p1_190001-194912.nc.ascii?lat
https://esgf.nci.org.au/thredds/dodsC/cmip5/output1/CSIRO-BOM/ACCESS1-0/historical/mon/atmos/Amon/r1i1p1/v20120727/zg/zg_Amon_ACCESS1-0_historical_r1i1p1_190001-194912.nc.ascii?lon
https://esgf.nci.org.au/thredds/dodsC/cmip5/output1/CSIRO-BOM/ACCESS1-0/historical/mon/atmos/Amon/r1i1p1/v20120727/zg/zg_Amon_ACCESS1-0_historical_r1i1p1_190001-194912.nc.ascii?plev
Note that array index subsetting begins at ‚Äú0‚Äù for the first element, see the query string in my example above.
Hopefully that will get you going!
Cheers,
Nathan

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Saleem,
I should also add that your e-mail software will probably butcher the links I sent by truncating the active link part (but not the displayed text) at a ‚Äú]‚Äù character. You will need to copy the entire URL - including the last ‚Äú]‚Äù and paste it into a terminal or browser as needed. Don‚Äôt rely on ‚Äúclicking‚Äù the links - they are unlikely to work correctly.
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.body:
Hi Saleem,
You have an extraneous period at the end of the URL path, just before the question mark. Remove the period and it should work.
Cheers,
Nathan

name.page: Re: [OPENDAP/bes] Add fileout_covjson module to bes (#105)
name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Feb 20, 2018, at 1:23 PM, Lewis John McGibbney <notifi...@github.com> wrote:
@rrimer07, @hemphilc, @RiverHendriksen and I are working on implementing a CovJSON module for serving CovJSON responses through a Hyrax deployment.
We will be submitting a PR for a feature branch in the short term, it will link to this issue.
Feature branch and PR: a good idea.
Regarding the question about SUBDIRS, I think you are not building the code correctly. Because the BES is a large project that has evolved from a collection of 17 interrelated projects, it has some quirks to its build.
For the issue you are asking about, run ‚Äòautoreconf -fiv‚Äô _only_ in the top level (bes) directory. Don‚Äôt run it anywhere else (e.g., do not run it in bes/modules). I believe that will fix this problem. If you are having a hard time building the BES, let me know ASAP. Many people do because the BES build _looks_ like a regular build for github + autotool, but it has a few quirks and if those steps are skipped or done out of order - both easy to do because otherwise it‚Äôs a ‚Äòstandard‚Äô auto tools build - they build will fail and you‚Äôll be left with the usual (inscrutable) auto tools error messages.
James
‚Äî
You are receiving this because you are subscribed to this thread.
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or mute the thread.
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.page: das file change between 1.13.1 and 1.13.5 (and maybe 1.14)
name.name: Mark Schwab
name.body:
Hi,
We had a user report getting errors with the formatting
of the .das metadata output from Opendap starting on
Friday. So, I rolled back opendap on our TS1 server,
and verified that the format change is directly related
to the update I made Thursday night.
The DAS file outputs from the same file from the two versions:
New version of opendap DAS file produced by 1.13.5 looks like:
<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center
DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
old version of opendap (1.13.1) :
<gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center
DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
--
Notice the extra 'amp;' in the 1.13.5 output.
--
I talked with Nathan Potter about this a little since I had him
looking at something else with me, and he tested it against
the current master in your repo and it went away again.
Other background...
The user is using PYDAP, a python opendap client and it breaks
his ability use this to get and manipulate the data, the paring
in the program can't handle that.
I think the user could download, remove that, and then use
his pydap script locally but, that seems like a nightmare.
Anyway, if this was an intentional change, then perhaps a
bug notice to the PYDAP developers is better, but if it's
not and they can fix it then that solves the issue too.
Thanks
Mark
__o
_-\<,
(_)/(_)___________________________________________________
Mark J. Schwab
Sr System Administator
Raytheon Systems
National Snow and Ice Data Center
University of Colorado
Campus Box 449 / 1540 30th St
Boulder, C0 80309
Ph: (303) 735-3061 Fax: (303) 492-2468
----------------------------------------------------------

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Mark,
Thanks for sending this in. I grabbed this HDF5 file:
https://n5eil01u.ecs.nsidc.org/opendap/SMAP/SPL3SMP.004/2015.04.06/SMAP_L3_SM_P_20150406_R14010_001.h5
And put it up on our test server which is running Hyrax-1.14.0 here:
http://test.opendap.org/opendap/NSIDC/contents.html
And it looks like the behavior has reverted to Hyrax-1.13.1 w.r.t. this metadata representation issue.
Also, I used the ‚Äúncdump‚Äù command line utility on the file and the metadata that it printed out matched what you are getting from Hyrax-1.13.5 (interesting‚Ä¶)
I am including Kent Yang (he is the keeper of the Hyrax HDF5 handler code) in the hopes that he can shed some light on this issue.
Cheers,
Nathan

name.page: das file change between 1.13.1 and 1.13.5 (and maybe 1.14)
name.name: Kent Yang
name.body:
Hi Nathan,Mark,
I havenÔøΩt changed the handling of DAS in the HDF5 handler for years. After checking the original HDF5 file, I think I find the reasons. That can also explain Nathan's ncdump output.
1)
In the original HDF5 file, there are two <gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString> strings.
One is <gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
Another one is <gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC > National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
IÔøΩve attached the ncdump output. I also checked h5dump and HDF5View. It both gave me the same results.
Inside attribute iso_19139_dataset_xml, you have <gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString>
2) The HDF5 handler with the current configuration will ignore iso_19139_dataset_xml due to its length. So <gco:CharacterString>NSIDC DAAC &gt; National Snow and Ice Data Center DAAC</gco:CharacterString> doesn't show up in the DAS output.
More details:
In the default HDF5 handler configuration:
Check file h5.conf,
There is a key H5.EnableDropLongString=true
The description of this key states:
# We find netCDF java has a string size limit(currently 32767). If an HDF5 string size
# is greater than this limit, visualization tools(Panoply etc.) that depend on
# the netCDF Java may not open the HDF5 file. So this key is set to be true to
# skip the HDF5 string of which size is greater than 32767. Users should set this
# key to false if that long string information is necessary or visualization clients
# are not used.
The size of iso_19139_dataset_xml is 182437, which is greater than 32767. So this long string is dropped.
To show this string, change H5.EnableDropLongString=false and restart your bes. You should see both <gco:CharacterString>..& gt and &gt... at your DAS.
BTW, I can use Panoply to check this SMAP product with this long string on although for other products(HIRDLS), Panoply still fails. Depending on the priority, I can change this
H5.EnableDropLongString=true
to
H5.EnableDropLongString=false
in the next release.
Best,
Kent
From: Nathan Potter [mailt...@opendap.org]
Sent: Wednesday, February 14, 2018 11:55 AM
To: Mark Schwab; Kent Yang
Cc: n...@opendap.org; User Support
Subject: Fwd: [support] das file change between 1.13.1 and 1.13.5 (and maybe 1.14)
cp

And put it up on our test server which is running Hyrax-1.14.0 here:
http://test.opendap.org/opendap/NSIDC/contents.html
And it looks like the behavior has reverted to Hyrax-1.13.1 w.r.t. this metadata representation issue.
Also, I used the ÔøΩncdumpÔøΩ command line utility on the file and the metadata that it printed out matched what you are getting from Hyrax-1.13.5 (interestingÔøΩ)
I am including Kent Yang (he is the keeper of the Hyrax HDF5 handler code) in the hopes that he can shed some light on this issue.
Cheers,
Nathan

name.name: hend...@oregonstate.edu
name.body:
Hello,
I'm working with a team to create a new BES response handler module, from what we have read the best method for doing this is using BES ./bescreatemodule located in the hyrax/bes/bin directory. However when compiling it errors out stating that they are specific files in the template directory which do not exist. We have looked at the current build on github and it does not contain those templates either. Is this method for creating a module defunct, and if so what is the best method for creating a new module in BES?
Thank you,
River

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Feb 12, 2018, at 21:23, hend...@oregonstate.edu wrote:
Hello,
I'm working with a team to create a new BES response handler module, from what we have read the best method for doing this is using BES ./bescreatemodule located in the hyrax/bes/bin directory. However when compiling it errors out stating that they are specific files in the template directory which do not exist. We have looked at the current build on github and it does not contain those templates either. Is this method for creating a module defunct, and if so what is the best method for creating a new module in BES?
At this point, yes, that code has seen any attention for a while and I‚Äôd be suspect of it. We should update our docs or the templates, or both. But, in the meantime, I‚Äôd suggest that you look for a module that does more or less what you want and copy that code. I‚Äôm guessing that you might be working on a module that returns JSON or some dialect thereof, so the fileout_json or the w10n_handler would be good places to start. I suspect that the former is the place to start.
We can help you understand how that code works - it‚Äôs not quite as hard as it looks, but like all framework systems, you really do need knowledge of the framework‚Äôs organization. Look first at the docs, then contact us if you still need help.
James
Thank you,
River
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Jan 24, 2018, at 00:46, Benedict Castro <benedict...@gmail.com> wrote:
Hi James,
I'm Benedict Castro, a researcher from the Philippines, and I am in need of assistance in performing the OPeNDAP Hyrax installation. I got your email from github since I was searching the web for easier ways to install the server. Upon looking at the OPENDAP github profile, I've seen there are repositories there on installation procedures. I'm not that proficient yet in this kind of work, so I wanted to know if how can I get started? Do I need to download all repositories? And what should I look first from those? Any kind of help will be appreciated. I hope you can help me on this endeavor. Thank you.
P.S. I'm working using CentOS 7.
There are two ways forward: You can build the Hyrax source code or install binaries. Have you tried installing the binaries we provide? Here‚Äôs the link if you have not: https://www.opendap.org/software/hyrax/1.14.0
That page also have a link to the server‚Äôs installation and configuration documentation. Installation is very straightforward on a C7 machine: get the RPMs and one WAR file, use yum to install the RPMs and copy the WAR file to the correct place. Start the server. Configuration can be very simple too, but depends on how many optional features you want to tweak.
Let me know if you need more information.
James
Best regards,
Benedict Z. Castro
Physical Oceanography Laboratory
The Marine Science Institute
University of the Philippines
Diliman, Quezon City
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Jan 24, 2018, at 18:35, Benedict Castro <benedict...@gmail.com> wrote:
Hi,
Good day!
As a summary, I have already installed java (1.8.0_161) and tomcat 8 on a CentOS 7 machine. I also tried installing the binaries but I had troubles in using BES. At first, I can start the BES, but upon reboot, I can no longer initialize it. I used sudo service besd start and the error that I've encountered is shown below:
/usr/bin/besctl start
Starting the BES
The besctl command cannot write to /var/run/bes.
Check that the directory exists and that the user running besctl has write permission for it.
So I tried to create that directory and fortunately I can start BES again. But after rebooting, the created /var/run/bes directory no longer exists and the error above reoccurs. I've tried searching solutions to the problem but no luck as of now. I've seen one, though, but it would mean reverting back to CentOS 6. Have you encountered this kind of problem before?
Yes. What‚Äôs happening here is that, in the second case, you‚Äôre running the BES as a regular user. When you use ‚Äòsudo service besd start‚Äô you‚Äôre starting the service as root and root can create directories, etc., everywhere.
Have you set the BES daemon to start up on boot? Since ‚Äòroot‚Äô handles that, the BES will start on boot. As a plus, you won‚Äôt have to remember to start it on every boot. Here‚Äôs a page that describes what to do for Centos 6, and 7 and Ubuntu. Unfortunately, the exact command differs between OSs.
https://geekflare.com/how-to-auto-start-services-on-boot-in-linux/
James
Thank you for the time and assistance.
Best regards,
Benedict
Benedict Z. Castro
Physical Oceanography Laboratory
The Marine Science Institute
University of the Philippines
Diliman, Quezon City
- show quoted text -
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

Hi Benedict,
1. Is that okay? Yes, should be OK, as temporary workaround, since we just need that directory to exist somehow (for now). We are modifying the RPM to ensure that this will no longer be a concern. We recommend using the -p option for mkdir, as advised below.
2. didn't find the file (and directory)...just FYI: The /var/lib/cloud/... directories should be installed in the Centos 7 AMI mentioned in message below and available at (just Google "Centos 7 AMI"):
https://aws.amazon.com/marketplace/pp/B00O7WM7QW
If still not there, you will need to perhaps look into cloud-init:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/23411408/how-do-i-set-up-cloud-init-on-custom-amis-in-aws-centos
3. text box with gray background. I just copied and pasted from our jira
https://opendap.atlassian.net/browse/HYRAX-600?focusedWorklogId=21534&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Aworklog-tabpanel#worklog-21534
to get codes below where I used {code} tag to generate the html needed like so:
{code}
This is some code
{code}
Thanks,
Uday Kari
On 2/5/18 5:28 PM, Benedict Castro wrote:
Hi Uday,
I didn't find the file (and directory) /var/lib/cloud/scripts/per-boot/per-boot.sh so what I did was I tried editing the /etc/init.d/besd file. There, I added the sudo mkdir /var/run/bes. Is that okay? Or would it cause problems in the future? So far, I haven't encountered any. Thanks!
On a side note, how do you write codes or scripts in a sort of text box with gray background as you did in your message? I'm just curious. Thanks!
Best regards,
Benedict Castro
Benedict Z. Castro
Physical Oceanography Laboratory
The Marine Science Institute
University of the Philippines
Diliman, Quezon City
On Tue, Feb 6, 2018 at 4:09 AM, Uday Kari <uk...@opendap.org> wrote:
Hi Benedict,
Thanks for reporting this issue. We are looking into this, so Hyrax is stable between reboots. We will provide a fix as soon as we have it done. For now, we have found that creating the /var/run/bes directory just before bes start will allow normal start. Specifically, with Centos 7 AMI, I was able to start BES on boot by editing (or add if not existing) the following file
/var/lib/cloud/scripts/per-boot/per-boot.sh
with following shell script
#!/bin/sh
sudo mkdir -p /var/run/bes
sudo besctl start
Thanks,
Uday Kari
- show quoted text -
--
Uday Kari
808-269-2740
uk...@opendap.org
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Sherry,
Can you send me the value of the ‚ÄúData URL‚Äù field from the form just prior to you pressing one of the ‚ÄúAction‚Äù buttons?
With that I can make a better assessment of where this is going wrong for you.
I tried the following:
I selecting just the ‚ÄústormHH‚Äù, ‚Äúnlat‚Äù, and ‚Äúnlon‚Äù variables in the form (no tinkering with the array subsets) and and then pressed the ‚ÄúGet ASCII‚Äù, ‚ÄúGet as NetCDF 4‚Äù, and ‚ÄúGets NetCDF 3‚Äù buttons.
In each case I got the data I expected.
Here are the request URLs that the form generated (when I pressed the associated ‚ÄúAction‚Äù button):

Note that you mail application will likely ignore the closing ‚Äú]‚Äù character in these URLs and in order to utilize them you will need to copy them and paste them into a browser‚Äôs address bar.
Cheers,
Nathan

Please inspect the ASCII response and you will see that the stormHH array does contain values:
https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/2005/3A25.20050801.7.HDF.ascii?stormHH[0:1:29][0:1:71][0:1:15],nlon[0:1:71],nlat[0:1:15],ncat2[0:1:29]
If you have the NetCDF tools on your system you can use ‚Äúncdump‚Äù from the command line to inspect the downloaded files:
ncdump 3A25.20050801.7.HDF.nc4
My guess is that you are only looking at the first layer of stormHH, stormHH[0][0:1:71][0:1:15], which appears to be all zeros. When I used the (free and awesome) Panoply application ( https://www.giss.nasa.gov/tools/panoply/ ) to open the data I was able to get nice images by fitting the ‚ÄúScale" (contour interval range) to the data and then selecting various ncat layers.
Panoply can open the downloaded NetCDF file, or it can work directly with the server:
Simply start Panoply, dismiss the pop-up that wants you to select a local file, and then under the ‚ÄúFile‚Äù menu select ‚ÄúOpen Remote Dataset‚Ä¶‚Äù and enter the URL:
https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/2005/3A25.20050801.7.HDF
Panoply will prompt you for your Earthdata Login credentials and then show you all of the variables in the file. Simply double click on ‚ÄústormHH‚Äù and Panoply should make a picture double quick. I fiddled with the settings under the ‚ÄúScale" tab and pretty quickly got reasonable images. But, as I said above, the first layer of stormHH, stormHH[0][0:1:71][0:1:15] appears to be all zero vales, but other layers stormHH[1:1:29][0:1:71][0:1:15] look good.
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Sherry,
The data look fine, and the values are reasonable.
The values for the variable ‚Äúnlat‚Äù range from -37.5 to 37.5 in one degree increments.
The values for the variable ‚Äúnlon‚Äù range from -177.5 to 177.5 in five degree increments.
The metadata records for both of these variables utilize the appropriate climate forecast (CF) conventions.
I suspect that the problem is not in the coordinate data, but rather it‚Äôs an issue with ArcGIS not being able to deal with the 3D array. I think that most GIS applications (including ArcGIS) don‚Äôt handle this kind of thing gracefully.
You might try downloading each ncat layer as a separate file and see if that will allow ArGIS to get it together:
https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/2005/3A25.20050801.7.HDF.nc?stormHH[0][0:1:71][0:1:15],nlon[0:1:71],nlat[0:1:15],ncat2[0]
https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/2005/3A25.20050801.7.HDF.nc?stormHH[1][0:1:71][0:1:15],nlon[0:1:71],nlat[0:1:15],ncat2[1]
https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/2005/3A25.20050801.7.HDF.nc?stormHH[2][0:1:71][0:1:15],nlon[0:1:71],nlat[0:1:15],ncat2[2]
https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/2005/3A25.20050801.7.HDF.nc?stormHH[3][0:1:71][0:1:15],nlon[0:1:71],nlat[0:1:15],ncat2[3]
And so on.
If that idea works, then you could automate the retrieval so you didn‚Äôt have to click your way through it..
In a bash shell you could do it like this:
for i in {0..29}
do
curl -s -g "https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/2005/3A25.20050801.7.HDF.nc?stormHH[$i][0:1:71][0:1:15],nlon[0:1:71],nlat[0:1:15],ncat2[$i]‚Äù > 3A25.20050801.7.ncat-$i.HDF.nc
done
You would have to configure curl to authenticate but that‚Äôs pretty quick work:
https://opendap.github.io/hyrax_guide/Master_Hyrax_Guide.html#_em_curl_em_a_k_a_em_lib_curl_em
Sincerely,
Nathan
> On Feb 5, 2018, at 7:58 AM, syoung20 <syou...@masonlive.gmu.edu> wrote:
>
> Hi Nathan,
>
> I need to open this in GIS. I got values on the storm height mean file but it isn't spatially referenced because the lat and long aren't given, it comes through as 0 to 71 for long etc. Is there a way to change this to actual lat and long? I can open it in GIS but just not once a coordinate system is designated.
>
> Thank you,
> Sherry

Hi Sherry,
If you look at the request form:
https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/2005/3A25.20050801.7.HDF.html
And scroll down to the ‚Äúncat2‚Äù variable in the little associated text box you should see:
units: level
comment: Second number of categories for histograms (30). Check more information from the references.
references: http://pps.gsfc.nasa.gov/Documents/filespec.TRMM.V7.pdf
Unfortunately the referenced PDF is of little value in this regard.
To try to find you additional information I did the following:
I looked at the URL of the service and noted this key bit: ‚Äúgesdisc‚Äù
So I went to the GES DISC site here:
https://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov
And I dropped the collection name ‚ÄúTRMM_3A25‚Äù into the search bar and it led me to this page:
https://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/datasets/TRMM_3A25_V7/summary?keywords=TRMM_3A25
And there in the documentation tab I found a link for ‚ÄúREADME Document‚Äù:
https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/data/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3A25/doc/README.TRMM_V7.pdf
Which does at least mention ncat2, but says little more:
‚Ä¢ The dimension ncat2 refers to the second number of categories for histograms (a total of 30)
I suspect that cryptic bit will not really help you.
There are other links on the TRMM_3A25 page including an email link for help at the bottom.
I‚Äôm not sure how much more help I can be on this, as I am just one of the authors of the Hyrax server software and not one of the domain scientists that understand this data set.
I hope that this will get you on your way!
Sincerely,
Nathan

On Dec 13, 2017, at 12:46, Kent Yang <mya...@hdfgroup.org> wrote:
Hi James/Nathan,
I recently tested the Hyrax 1.14.0 release RPMs at my CentOS 7 virtual box. I found that even if I changed
BES.Catalog.catalog.FollowSymLinks=No
To
BES.Catalog.catalog.FollowSymLinks=Yes
And
BES.FollowSymLinks=No
To
BES.FollowSymLinks=Yes
I still don‚Äôt see the symbolically linked served files.
I then built libdap and bes from the source code and followed the same steps above. I can see the symbolically linked served files. I am wondering why symbolic links don‚Äôt work when installing Hyrax via RPMs. Have you tested out this feature?
Check that the paths you‚Äôre linking into the RootDirectory are readable by the ‚Äòbes‚Äô user - the RPM packages contain a BES daemon that runs as ‚Äòbes‚Äô while the source builds generally run as whoever runs besctl or besd.
It‚Äôs tedious, but you must check all the parts of the paths. In fact, based on your report, it‚Äôs likely that the problem is not with the directory you‚Äôve linked to, but one of its parent directories.
Let me know if this resolves the issue.
James

Kent

But I'm not sure what format the inputs should be in and I'm getting this error:
Error {
code = 3;
message = "Invalid Parameter Exception: DArrayDimension.setProjection: Bad Projection Request: stop >= size: 2013:1968";
};
What I needis data from 2013 onwards. Can you please advise?
Also, is there a data dictionary / data description somewhere?
Many thanks in advance for your help,
