--
YARA ABU AWAD | Postdoctoral Research Fellow
Department of Environmental Health | Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health
401 Park Drive | 4th floor West, office 408-A | Boston, MA 02215
o: 617-384-8804 | c: 857-277-2631
yabu...@hsph.harvard.edu

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Yara,
This form (produced by an instance of the THREDDS Data Server, aka TDS), accepts only index based constraints where ‚Äú0‚Äù is the index of the first element. In order to subset by value you need to look at the values of the MAP arrays (time, lat, and lon) to determine which indices correspond to your desired value based boundaries.
You can easily get the values of lat (latitude) by selecting just the lat array and then clicking the ‚ÄúGet ASCII‚Äù button. The form builds a request URL:
https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/thredds/dodsC/Datasets/20thC_ReanV2c/Monthlies/gaussian/monolevel/hpbl.mon.mean.nc.ascii?lat[0:1:93]
And then opens that in a new window.
(Caveat: Your emailer may well not include the closing square bracket ‚Äú]‚Äù when it sees these links and without it none of the, will work. You may need to copy and paste the link into a browser or a terminal window by hand)
For example, if you wanted latitudes such that 50>lat>40 then you would request 21:1:25 where 21 is the first index, the stride is 1, and 25 is the last index:
https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/thredds/dodsC/Datasets/20thC_ReanV2c/Monthlies/gaussian/monolevel/hpbl.mon.mean.nc.ascii?lat[21:1:25]
You can do the same for longitude (lon) and time.
The metadata (data dictionary) for each variable appears in the text box associated with the variable in the form. This is especially important for the time variable as its units are described as "units: hours since 1800-1-1 00:00:0.0‚Äù. So in order for you to convert your desired time range into the index space you will need to figure out what your start date is in the units "hours since 1800-1-1 00:00:0.0‚Äù. This can be accomplished in a couple of steps by using an online tool like:
https://www.epochconverter.com
Since these tools typically have the epoch fixed at "1970-1-1 00:00:0.0‚Äù you would first find the value of the "1800-1-1 00:00:0.0‚Äù relative to "1970-1-1 00:00:0.0‚Äù (-5364662400 seconds) and then the value of your desired start time, say "2013-1-1 00:00:0.0‚Äù (1356998400 seconds) and then (5364662400 + 1356998400 = 6721660800 seconds since 1800-1-1 00:00:0.0 ) Convert this to hours by dividing by 60 to get minutes and again by 60 to get the desired hours since "1800-1-1 00:00:0.0": 1867128
I used curl and an inline awk script to find the values that match:
curl https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/thredds/dodsC/Datasets/20thC_ReanV2c/Monthlies/gaussian/monolevel/hpbl.mon.mean.nc.ascii?time[0:1:1967] | awk '{if(NR==6){ gsub(",","",$0); n=split($0,a," ");for(i=1;i<=n;i++){if(a[i]>=1867128)print i-1, a[i];} }}‚Äô -
Which output:
1944 1867128.0
1945 1867872.0
1946 1868544.0
1947 1869288.0
1948 1870008.0
1949 1870752.0
1950 1871472.0
1951 1872216.0
1952 1872960.0
1953 1873680.0
1954 1874424.0
1955 1875144.0
1956 1875888.0
1957 1876632.0
1958 1877304.0
1959 1878048.0
1960 1878768.0
1961 1879512.0
1962 1880232.0
1963 1880976.0
1964 1881720.0
1965 1882440.0
1966 1883184.0
1967 1883904.0
So for time > "2013-1-1 00:00:0.0‚Äù I found the index based time subset would be [1944:1:1967]
I hope that helps!
Please let us know if you need more assistance.
Sincerely,
Nathan
- show quoted text -
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Corey,
I think your BES is is not working correctly. It may be that components failed to build, or that the configuration is incorrect. Since you are working on Ubuntu I‚Äôm pretty sure you are building from source. If that‚Äôs not the case not let me know, otherwise I‚Äôll need to start with the basics
- Which directions are you following to build the software?
- Did the hyrax-dependencies project build with out error? This is important, and that particular build will not stop on error so you should go back into that project and run make again (with the ‚Äúprefix‚Äù ENV var set as directed) and scan the output for errors.
- Did the libdap4 project build and pass all tests (i.e. ‚Äúmake check‚Äù)? Did you install it?
- When you built the BES where you able to successfully run ‚Äúmake check‚Äù?
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Corey,
It looks like somewhere you forgot a key step - probably you configured and built libdap before you conditioned your shell environment by sourcing ‚Äúspath.sh‚Äù.
Here is a recovery plan:
0) Get thee to the top of the hyrax directories
cd /home/ubuntu/hyrax; # Or wherever it is that you put all the source code.
1) Uninstall what you have done:
cd bes; make uninstall; cd ..
cd libdap4; make uninstall; cd ..
2) Now, before you do ANYTHING else source ‚Äúspath.sh‚Äù in your current shell!
source spath.sh; echo $prefix
3) If ‚Äúecho $prefix‚Äù doesn‚Äôt look correct then let‚Äôs discuss.
4) Make sure that the ‚Äúhyrax-dependencies‚Äù have been built and are installed in ‚Äú$prefix/deps‚Äù
cd hyrax-dependencies; make
5) Reconfigure and rebuild libdap4:
cd libdap4; autoreconf -vif; ./configure --prefix=$prefix --enable-developer;
make -j9; make -j9 check; make install; cd ..
6) And now the BES:
cd bes; autoreconf -vif; ./configure --prefix=$prefix --with-dependencies=$prefix/deps --enable-developer;
make -j9; make -j9 check; make install; cd ..
7) Try launching the BES again‚Ä¶
besctl start
Sorry about the (re)grind here, but the error makes it clear that libdap is not located where the BES thinks it should be.
Cheers,
Nathan
- show quoted text -
> <bes_make_check.txt><libdap_make_check.txt>
- show quoted text -

name.name: hemp...@oregonstate.edu
name.body:
Nathan,
1) Uninstall what you have done:
I did you one better and re-cloned the repo.
2) Now, before you do ANYTHING else source ‚Äúspath.sh‚Äù in your current shell!
source spath.sh; echo $prefix
$prefix = "/home/ubuntu/hyrax/build"
3) If ‚Äúecho $prefix‚Äù doesn‚Äôt look correct then let‚Äôs discuss.
4) Make sure that the ‚Äúhyrax-dependencies‚Äù have been built and are installed in ‚Äú$prefix/deps‚Äù
hyrax-dependencies; make
I see all dependencies installed successfully to $prefix/deps
5) Reconfigure and rebuild libdap4:
cd libdap4; autoreconf -vif; ./configure --prefix=$prefix --enable-developer;
make -j9; make -j9 check; make install; cd ..
All successful
6) And now the BES:
cd bes; autoreconf -vif; ./configure --prefix=$prefix --with-dependencies=$prefix/deps --enable-developer;
make -j9; make -j9 check; make install; cd ..
All successful
7) Try launching the BES again‚Ä¶
besctl start
bes started successfully.
I am now able to access http://localhost:8080/opendap. Everything seems to be in working order!
Your help has been very much appreciated. Thank you!
Cheers,
-Corey

name.name: Rosul, Lauren Marie
name.body:
Hello,
I am in need of a complete data set for hurricane Ike in order to visualize the model results in ArcGIS software. I am specifically interested in the model results from https://ioos.us/comt/projects/tropical_inundation . I am unfamiliar with this type of data access form is there a way to request the entire set in an appropriate format for my needs?
Thank You For your help,
-Lauren Rosul
Lauren Rosul
M.S. Geoscience
lmr...@uncw.edu
Socio Environmental Analysis Lab
Department of Earth and Ocean Science
University of North Carolina Wilmington

name.name: Nathan Potter
Roy Mendelssohn - NOAA Federal
name.body:
Hi Lauren:
Based on what I at say:
https://ioos.us/comt/projects/tropical_inundation/slosh--mdl--egm3?t=Effect%20of%20wind%20input%20parameterizations%20on%20hurricane%20wave%20estimation%20Hurricane%20Ike%20landfall%20ADCIRC+SWAN%20Sensitivity%20Unstructured%20surge-wave%20models%20Comparison%20of%202-D%20and%203-D%20model%20responses%20Hurricane%20IkeHurricane%20Rita
There are WMS endpoints for the data, and depending on what you are trying to do that might be a better solution for ArcGIS. Or if you need the data also, not just the image, you can try installing the Environmental Data Connector into ArcGIS, which would allow you to access the OPenDAP endpoint. This is available at:
http://asascience.com/software/downloads/
But in either case, I would second Nathan's warning. These are very large datasets. I would strongly suggest that you spend some time becoming more familiar with the datasets, and think about the size of the datasets and what you really need, otherwise almost any request is likely to crash the program. One nice thing about using WMS or OPeNDAP, in each request you can request just the variable you need for just the locations you need. But even then, if you are not careful, the request can be very large, because it is a very fine grid.
HTH,
-Roy

name.name: Tolley, Stuart
name.body:
Dear Sir/Madame,
I am currently trying to download data using your dataset access form, however I am finding it very difficult to understand. The data I am trying to access is:
Project= CMIP5
model=HadGEM2-es
experiment=RCP4.5
The main variable I'm looking for is pH.
The specific area I need it in is a region of sea off the British Coastline:
Latitude= 51-52
Longitude= 1.7-2.55.
The time I require if for the year 2050 and 2100.

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:

Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Stuart,
I do not have access to ESGF data which limits my ability to provide specific detailed instructions.
To simplify your challenge I suggest you try using a client program that understands the data access protocol.
I believe Ferret can work, as can Panoply and Matlab. Panoply is free and might just make it very easy.
https://www.giss.nasa.gov/tools/panoply/
And I think (depending on how ESGF implement their OpenID portal) that Panoply will be able to navigate the authentication transaction.
If you try Panoply simply dismiss the file chooser that launches at start up. Go to the ‚ÄúFile" menu and select ‚ÄúOpen Remote Dataset‚Ä¶‚Äù and enter the URL:
http://esgf-data1.ceda.ac.uk/thredds/dodsC/cmip5.output1.MOHC.HadGEM2-ES.rcp45.mon.ocnBgchem.Omon.r4i1p1.ph.20120110.aggregation.1
And see what happens - with luck, after you authenticate, you should be able to select variables from within the dataset and do things like plot, subset, etc.
More comments below...
> On Jan 26, 2018, at 2:48 AM, Tolley, Stuart <st...@exeter.ac.uk> wrote:
>
> Hi Nathan,
>
> Unfortunately I'm still pretty confused with the strides and the arrays etc. I'm an undergraduate student and it's all a bit baffling.
>
> This is the data I wish to download:
>
> <pastedImage.png>
>
> When I click OpenDAP download it just attempts to download something which cannot be supported by my computer. When I click a link for THREDDS Catalog I can gain access to the OpenDAP data access form. So if I want to find out the pH in 2100 for an area of ocean between latitudes: 51-52 and longitudes: 1.7-2.55 how should it look? should it be 51:1:52?
Without data access (because I do not have authentication credentials in ESGF) I do not have access t the data and so I cannot verify that you subset is correct. But from look at you question I think you‚Äôre not understanding the difference between index based subsetting and values based subsetting. These servers support index based subsetting. So, I am going to paste in a previous response I made for a different user that outlines how to figure out your subset values by hand. The URLs and data are different, but the concepts are the same. So for YOUR example the base URL should be, I believe,
http://esgf-data1.ceda.ac.uk/thredds/dodsC/cmip5.output1.MOHC.HadGEM2-ES.rcp45.mon.ocnBgchem.Omon.r4i1p1.ph.20120110.aggregation.1
You can get a quick sense of the structure by looking at the DDS:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.dds
( http://esgf-data1.ceda.ac.uk/thredds/dodsC/cmip5.output1.MOHC.HadGEM2-ES.rcp45.mon.ocnBgchem.Omon.r4i1p1.ph.20120110.aggregation.1.dds )
(NB: from here forward the example uses the example URL and not the one you supplied, you will be seeing different data structures and most likely different variable names, you will have to adjust accordingly)
Which shows you how it‚Äôs represented:
Dataset {
Float32 Longitude[Longitude = 2160];
Float32 Lon_bounds[Longitude = 2160][nv = 2];
Float32 Latitude[Latitude = 960];
Float32 Lat_bounds[Latitude = 960][nv = 2];
Float32 Time_bounds[Time = 1][nv = 2];
Float32 Time[Time = 1];
Grid {
Array:
Float32 SLA_ERR[Time = 1][Longitude = 2160][Latitude = 960];
Maps:
Float32 Time[Time = 1];
Float32 Longitude[Longitude = 2160];
Float32 Latitude[Latitude = 960];
} SLA_ERR;
Grid {
Array:
Float32 SLA[Time = 1][Longitude = 2160][Latitude = 960];
Maps:
Float32 Time[Time = 1];
Float32 Longitude[Longitude = 2160];
Float32 Latitude[Latitude = 960];
} SLA;
} ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc;
I worked the issue using the ‚Äúmanual‚Äù method, tedious but doable. It‚Äôs far preferable to write a small shell script or python program to do the following for you.
To find the extents you‚Äôll have to inspect the Latitude and Longitude arrays to determine the indices of your bounding values. You wanted:
> 284.167 to 255.167 for longitude and 34.1667 to 12.1667 for latitude
It‚Äôs simple to get the server to return data as ascii values. This is done by modifying the URL, and then, since the data are large, restricting the request to return just the Longitude values (Note how I modified the dataset URL with the suffix ‚Äú.ascii‚Äù and then added a ‚Äú?" followed by the name of the longitude array ‚ÄúLongitude"
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude
But thats a bunch of points so we can look at a smaller ranges:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1520:1:1540]
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1720:1:1730]
Which I determined by estimation.
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1530]
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1729]
The closest longitude indices that include your desired interval are 1530 and 1729
So the longitude subset is:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1530:1:1729]
Similarly we can determine the latitude bounds:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Latitude
Similarly, I poked at it until I got:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Latitude[552]
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Latitude[685]
So the latitude subset is:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Latitude[552:1:685]
Now we can make the data request. You can use the data request form here:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.html
and select the SLA grid at the bottom and then insert the Longitude subset expression 1530:1:1729 and the Latitude subset expression 552:1:685 into the form and then use the buttons at the top to make the request.
Alternately you can do it by building the data request URLs as follows:
ASCII https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?SLA[0:1:0][1530:1:1729][552:1:685]
NetCDF-3 https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.nc?SLA[0:1:0][1530:1:1729][552:1:685]
NetCDF-4 https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.nc4?SLA[0:1:0][1530:1:1729][552:1:685]
And use those with a browser or the ‚Äúcurl‚Äù program from the command line.
If you have a large number of these to do I think you will be best served writing a small shell script or python program to do this for you!
I hope that helps‚Ä¶
Sincerely,
Nathan
> please explain this to me as simply as you can I have not had much experience with this sort of thing.
>
> Additionally, is Ferret via Oracle VirtualBox the best way to open this data?
>
> Thanks,
>
> Stuart
> From: Nathan Potter <n...@opendap.org>
> Sent: Thursday, January 25, 2018 2:54:35 PM
> To: Tolley, Stuart; THREDDS community
> Cc: Nathan Potter
> Subject: Re: [support] Data Request
>
> Hi Stuart,
>
> Unfortunately I do not have access credentials for any of the OpenID providers listed at that site and thus am unable to view that dataset. However from the URL I can see that the software that is providing access is not Hyrax, but rather the THREDDS Data Server (TDS), the form interface is roughly the same as the one the we provide with Hyrax so the documentation link I sent is relevant.
>
> The form utilizes array index based subsetting, not value based subsetting. For your request you would need to examine the longitude and latitude arrays to determine the indices of the bounding box you wish to subset. This can be done quickly by selecting one the coordinate variables (pick for example the variable for latitude) by selecting just that in the form and then clicking on the ‚ÄúGet ASCII‚Äù button. (You may need to do a bit of scripting to find the indices of the bounds) Repeat for longitude. Once you can express them as start:stride:stop you can select the variable you wish to retrieve (pH for example) and plug those index values into the appropriate part of the form. Using the form you can then retrieve the results as either an ASCII download or as a DAP2 binary object.
>
> The TDS provides several other (possibly more intuitive) ways to request data, but I am not entirely familiar with them so I am including the TDS support list so that they can chime in and assist you.
>
> Cheers,
>
> Nathan
>
>
> > On Jan 25, 2018, at 6:35 AM, Tolley, Stuart <st...@exeter.ac.uk> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Nathan,
> >
> > This is the URL I am hoping to use: http://esgf-data1.ceda.ac.uk/thredds/dodsC/cmip5.output1.MOHC.HadGEM2-ES.rcp45.mon.ocnBgchem.Omon.r4i1p1.ph.20120110.aggregation.1
> >
> > Thank you in advance for any assistance you can provide.
> >
> > Regards,
> >
> > Stuart
> > From: Nathan Potter <n...@opendap.org>
> > Sent: Thursday, January 25, 2018 1:57:48 PM
> > To: Tolley, Stuart
> > Cc: Nathan Potter; sup...@opendap.org
> > Subject: Re: [support] Data Request

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Huber,
So you do have to be the root user to start the BES. The BES quickly changes it‚Äôs runtime PID to be the user ‚Äúbes‚Äù, but because of the daemonic nature of the BES it must be started as the root user:
sudo service best start
or
sudo besctl start
should do it. Remember - it does not continue to run as root. You just have to be root to launch it.
Thanks,
Nathan
> On Sep 24, 2017, at 8:06 AM, Huber Gilt Lopez <hg...@igp.gob.pe> wrote:
>
> Hello Nathan
>
> Thank you for your help, these are the outputs from your request.
>
> 1)
>
> [root@hyrax ~]# service besd status
> /usr/bin/besctl status
> Could not find the BES PID file
>
> [root@hyrax ~]# service besd start
> /usr/bin/besctl start
> Starting the BES
> The besctl command cannot write to /var/run/bes.
> Check that the directory exists and that the user running
> besctl has write permissions for it.
>
> 2)
>
> I only can run it as root user, but this an another question. I've got the following messages when I used an other user. How can I run the "besd" service as a non-privileged user?
>
> /usr/bin/besctl start
> Starting the BES
> FAILED: Must be root to run BES
> FAILED: The BES daemon did not appear to start
You cannot START the best as a non-root user. But it never RUNS as the root user, it always changes to a different user downstream.
>
> 3)
>
> [root@hyrax ~]# ps aux | grep bes
> root 1094 0.0 0.0 112680 968 pts/0 S+ 09:52 0:00 grep --color=auto bes
>
> After, I created manually the directory /var/run/bes, I can start the service.
>
> [root@hyrax ~]# ps aux | grep bes
> bes 1247 0.4 0.4 349420 25336 ? Ss 09:47 0:00 /usr/bin/besdaemon -i /usr -c /etc/bes/bes.conf -r /var/run/bes
> bes 1249 0.4 0.4 350256 25840 ? Ss 09:47 0:00 /usr/bin/beslistener -c /etc/bes/bes.conf -d /var/log/bes/bes.log,-ascii,-besdaemon,-csv,-dap,-ff,-fits,-fojson,-fonc,-fong,-gateway,-gdal,-h4,-h5,-nc,-ncml,-ppt,-reader,-server,-usage,-w10n,-www,-xd -i /usr -r /var/run/bes
> root 1263 0.0 0.0 112680 968 pts/0 S+ 09:48 0:00 grep --color=auto bes
>
> [root@hyrax ~]# grep -E "^(BES\.User|BES\.Group)" /etc/bes/bes.conf
> BES.User=bes
> BES.Group=bes
>
> 4)
>
> [root@hyrax ~]# ls -la /var/run/bes
> total 4
> drwxrwxr-x 2 bes bes 60 sep 24 09:53 .
> drwxr-xr-x 23 root root 780 sep 24 09:52 ..
> -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17 sep 24 09:53 bes.pi
>
> Also I attached the my bes.conf.
>
> Thank you for your help.
>
> Best regards
> Huber
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "Nathan Potter" <n...@opendap.org>
> To: "Huber Gilt Lopez" <hg...@igp.gob.pe>
> Cc: "Nathan Potter" <n...@opendap.org>
> Sent: Sunday, September 24, 2017 8:09:54 AM
> Subject: Re: About OPeNDAP Hyrax Release
>
> Hi Huber,
>
> Looks like some kind of permissions problem. I need some information about what is going on in your system.
>
> Can you please tell me:
>
> 1) What command did you issue that gave you the error?
>
> 2) What user were you when you issued the command?
>
> 3) What are the user and group of the beslistener and besdaemon processes?
> - Check the running process:
> ps aux | grep bes
> - Check the BES config:
> grep -E "^(BES\.User|BES\.Group)‚Äù /etc/bes/bes.conf
>
> 4) The output of ‚Äúls -la /var/run/bes‚Äù?
>
> My thinking is that somewhere in this collection of things that the permissions have be assigned incorrectly.
>
>
>
> Sincerely,
>
> Nathan
>
>
>> On Sep 23, 2017, at 5:20 PM, Huber Gilt Lopez <hg...@igp.gob.pe> wrote:
>>
>> Hello Nathan
>>
>> I thought that I installed the Hyrax server correctly, but after restart the linux Centos 7.4. I noticed that the bes service doesn't start at boot time. Then I trying to restart manually and I get the following message:
>>
>> Shutting down the BES daemon
>> The BES daemon is not currently running
>> Starting the BES
>> The besctl command cannot write to /var/run/bes.
>> Check that the directory exists and that the user running

name.name: Marcelo Duran Burgos
name.body:
Dear Friends of Ocean Color, my name is Marcelo Duran and I work in CIREN (Center of information of natural resources) of the Ministry of Agriculture in Chile. We are in a project to survey surface variables of the Chilean sea, so we come to your page and find the data we need. The problem is that your web page only allows you to download the images one by one. My question is, is there any option to download these satellite products in volume (several at once)?
Waiting for your answer
Best regards from Chile
MARCELO E. DUR√ÅN BURGOS
Profesional Geom√°tico
(56 02) 2200 89 29
mduran@ciren.cl
http://www.ciren.cl

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Marcelo,
Our group supports the server software that provides the access to the data in which you are interested.
There are several implementations of this type of server (aka as a DAP server), and because of this there are
several different ways, some server dependent, to address your question.
In order for me to effectively help you I will need the URL of the site from which you are attempting to retrieve your data.
Sincerely,
Nathan
For me to effectively help you
> On Jan 19, 2018, at 5:25 AM, Marcelo Duran Burgos <mdu...@ciren.cl> wrote:
>
> Dear Friends of Ocean Color, my name is Marcelo Duran and I work in CIREN (Center of information of natural resources) of the Ministry of Agriculture in Chile. We are in a project to survey surface variables of the Chilean sea, so we come to your page and find the data we need. The problem is that your web page only allows you to download the images one by one. My question is, is there any option to download these satellite products in volume (several at once)?
>
> Waiting for your answer
>
> Best regards from Chile
>
>
> MARCELO E. DUR√ÅN BURGOS
> Profesional Geom√°tico
> (56 02) 2200 89 29
> mdu...@ciren.cl
> http://www.ciren.cl
>
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: Marcelo Duran Burgos
name.body:
Dear Friend Nathan, thank you very much for the speed of your management.
Attached is the link of the files I want to download, from 2002 to 2018.
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/MODISA/L3SMI/contents.html
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/MODIST/L3SMI/contents.html
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/VIIRS/L3SMI/contents.html
Waiting for your answer
best regards

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Marcelo,
The links that you provided point to OPeNDAP servers which are not designed for file downloads, but rather for subsetting data by selecting variables and applying constraint expressions. If what you want is to simply retrieve the files, NASA has a different service for that activity.
I believe that this URL:
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov
Will lead you to the download pages for all of the collections you named. To download these files in bulk (or in volume as you said) I suggest you use the program wget to do so. You can point it at one of the URL‚Äôs for the collection you are interested in:
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/MODIS-Aqua/L3SMI/
And it will crawl through it and get all of the things you specify. The wget application is powerful and has a lengthy manual page that you will need to read (or use Google to find out more about it).
https://www.gnu.org/software/wget/
Most Linux/Unix distributions (including Apple‚Äôs OSX) either have wget installed to it can be installed using the nominal package manager of the system (i.e. yum, apt-get, etc.)
Also, many of NASA‚Äôs data sites require a login using the Earthdata Login system before a data download can be completed.
It does not appear to me that this particular service requires the use of Earthdata Login.
However, if you do encounter it in the future, wget can work with it after some configuration steps.
You can read more about it here:
https://urs.earthdata.nasa.gov/
https://opendap.github.io/hyrax_guide/Master_Hyrax_Guide.html#_authentication_for_dap_clients
https://opendap.github.io/hyrax_guide/Master_Hyrax_Guide.html#_em_wget_em
I hope that gets you going.
Sincerely,
Nathan
On Jan 19, 2018, at 6:45 AM, Marcelo Duran Burgos <mdu...@ciren.cl> wrote:
Dear Friend Nathan, thank you very much for the speed of your management.
Attached is the link of the files I want to download, from 2002 to 2018.
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/MODISA/L3SMI/contents.html
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/MODIST/L3SMI/contents.html
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/VIIRS/L3SMI/contents.html
Waiting for your answer
best regards
- show quoted text -
- show quoted text -

name.name: Marcelo Duran Burgos
name.body:
Dear friend, thank you for your help, but even so I have tried all the morning to download with WGET and the only thing I can achieve is to download the whole website which does not work for me. Only the images serve me. The error he says to me is "Resolving - (-) ... failed: Temporary failure in name resolution.
wget: unable to resolve host address '-' ".
Below is an example of what I want to download:
wget https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/MODIS-Aqua/L3BIN/2010/001/*.nc --no-check-certificate
If you could give me one last help like downloading HTTPS sites and NC files with WGET.
Best regards
Atte

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Marcelo,
I think you may be confused about what is actually available from the site. This site contains data files, not image files. The data are stored in NetCDF format which is a self-describing structured data format. NetCDF files are not images. If you are unfamiliar with NetCDF then I think you will need to either learn about it or avail yourself to one of a number of free of tools that can read a NetCDF file and produce/plot an image from the data inside.
You might consider using Panoply to access these data:
https://www.giss.nasa.gov/tools/panoply/
Download and install Panoply. When you launch it simply dismiss the file selection dialog that launches at start up by pressing the ‚ÄúCancel‚Äù button. Goto the File menu and select ‚ÄúOpen Remote Catalog‚Ä¶‚Äù. In the resulting pop window you can enter any of the following links (which are the machine readable catalog information generated by the Hyrax server):
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/MODISA/L3SMI/catalog.xml
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/MODIST/L3SMI/catalog.xml
https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/opendap/VIIRS/L3SMI/catalog.xml
Panoply knows how to work with these and will allow you to select datasets, choose variables, and create images of the data. I don‚Äôt know if Panoply has a batch processing ability, you will need to read about it to find out. Regardless, it‚Äôs free and fairly easy to use. For example once you drill down to a dataset all you have to do is double clink on the variable you wish to plot, for example ‚Äúchl_ocx‚Äù, and Panoply will construct a plot for you.
More about downloading with wget follows inline below.
> On Jan 22, 2018, at 6:53 AM, Marcelo Duran Burgos <mdu...@ciren.cl> wrote:
>
> Dear friend, thank you for your help, but even so I have tried all the morning to download with WGET and the only thing I can achieve is to download the whole website which does not work for me. Only the images serve me. The error he says to me is "Resolving - (-) ... failed: Temporary failure in name resolution.
> wget: unable to resolve host address '-' ".
>
> Below is an example of what I want to download:
> wget https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/MODIS-Aqua/L3BIN/2010/001/*.nc --no-check-certificate
This command will not work because the shell (bash, csh, etc.) will interpret the ‚Äú*‚Äù and make a mess of it. You have to use a more carefully crafted wget command. In particular you will need to submit the base URL along with a regular expression to define an ‚Äúaccept list‚Äù
In your example above I think you would need something along the lines of:
wget -r -e robots=off -A "*.nc" -l1 https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/MODIS-Aqua/L3BIN/2010/001
But if you want all of the files you would want to start higher in the URL path:
wget -r -e robots=off -A "*.nc" -l1 https://oceandata.sci.gsfc.nasa.gov/MODIS-Aqua/L3BIN/
See:
https://www.gnu.org/software/wget/manual/wget.html#Recursive-Accept_002fReject-Options
https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/117988/wget-with-wildcards-in-http-downloads
>
> If you could give me one last help like downloading HTTPS sites and NC files with WGET.
Please consider utilizing Google searches and reading the wget manual. I am by no means a wget expert and I was only able to provide the above examples by reading the wget manual pages and using Google to search for the phrase "wget matching files‚Äù.
I hope that helps.
Sincerely,
Nathan
>
> Best regards
>
> Atte
- show quoted text -

name.name: Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]
name.body:
Hi. Our Hyrax user reported a problem I‚Äôve never noticed. It is also difficult to reproduce. They claimed that the ddx response can occasionally list the variables in a data granule twice.
It appears to happen with NcML granules, and reported cases are a few of our AIRS datasets. We enhance the metadata in these datasets to add variable attributes like ‚Äòunits‚Äô and ‚Äòlong_name‚Äô etc. in the NcML files. By inspecting their attached ddx I can see that the first time the ddx listed variables, e.g. ‚ÄòTotalCounts_A‚Äô correctly by including the ‚Äòlong_name‚Äô, and the second time it listed ‚ÄòTotalCount_A‚Äô without ‚Äòlong_name‚Äô. In fact the second listing for all variable looks just like what would be reported in ddx had the server accessed the original HDF data. It may sound like the server is attempting to access the original HDF granule and somehow combine the metadata. However if a repeat request was made (by e.g. a second wget or simply reloading the browser) the ddx would correctly list one single case of the variables with NcML enhancement. It is this behavior that made it difficult to reproduce the problem.
You may attempt to reproduce it with the granules here but it is not guaranteed that you‚Äôd be hitting it the first time (and not sure since when):
https://acdisc.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/hyrax/ncml/Aqua_AIRS_Level3/AIRS3STD.006/2005/contents.html
Our user didn‚Äôt report if this happened to das or dds. I suppose there is a machine interface reading the ddx.
If it cannot be reliably reproduced, I guess this becomes a theoretical question: is it possible that server ddx response can access a link (in this case the original HDF granule) in an NcML file under certain circumstances? Is it possible that the server ddx can read any cache entries pointing to a data resource with similar filenames (we append .ncml to an HDF granule name)? Other possibilities?
Thanks.
-Fan

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Fan,
I spent some time on this and I have yet to reproduce the issue :(
I‚Äôve made a ticket https://opendap.atlassian.net/browse/HYRAX-593 and added it to the bug list.
In order to reproduce this it would be really helpful if you could make available an example of one of the data files and it‚Äôs associated NcML file so I can run this on one of our dev systems. (One that I can restart with at will)
Thanks,
Nathan
- show quoted text -
> <AIRS.2002.10.06.L3.RetStd_IR001.v6.0.9.0.G13215142846.hdf.ncml.ddx>
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]
name.body:
Hi Nathan,
The HDF granules are available from here (assuming you have EarthData login; otherwise look here https://wiki.earthdata.nasa.gov/display/EL/How+To+Register+With+Earthdata+Login )
https://acdisc.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/data/s4pa/Aqua_AIRS_Level3/AIRS3STD.006/2005/
I attach a sample NcML file, in which you‚Äôd need to change the ‚Äòlocation‚Äô attribute value of the <netcdf/> element at the top to point to wherever you have the granule in your server under opendap data root.
Here is some additional info that might be useful: our ‚Äôacdisc‚Äô server uses the 1.13.4 release, and we use data and metadata caches (which I figured might be relevant given the temporal behavior) implemented in the HDF4 and HDF5 handlers. In this case only the HDF4 configuration is relevant. Therefore I attached the bes.conf, h4.conf, and ncml.conf that the server uses. Let me know if you need anything else.
Thanks for taking this on ‚Äì I thought it would be challenging.
-Fan

Fan,
Thanks I added all that to the ticket.
Nathan

name.page: Downloading multiple MERR2 files using wget from the command line
name.name: Hegarty, Jennifer
name.body:
Dear Support:
I would like to create a script that uses wget or some other utility to download multiple MERRA files without having to get through the web application to select these files every time. When I try to use wget to retrieve these files using the data url (e.g., http://goldsmr4.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/hyrax/MERRA2/M2I3NXGAS.5.12.4/2017/08/MERRA2_400.inst3_2d_gas_Nx.20170823.nc4) I get a 403 Forbidden error. I have set up an account on the GES DISC and have created a .netrc file on my home directory. The only way I have ever gotten this to work is to through the web application subset data and then use the .inp file it creates. However, this is a cumbersome process and I would like to be able to automate it in a script. Could you please advise me how to do this.
Thank you for your help.
Jen
AER
131 Hartwell Avenue
Lexington, MA 02421
781-761-2377

name.page: Downloading multiple MERR2 files using wget from the command line
name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Jennifer,
I believe that all of the OPeNDAP servers at NASA are configured to block file downloads.
This URL:
https://goldsmr4.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/hyrax/MERRA2/M2I3NXGAS.5.12.4/2017/08/MERRA2_400.inst3_2d_gas_Nx.20170823.nc4
Will not work. Try that link in a browser.
I went to https://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov and searched for ‚ÄúM2I3NXGAS" which led me to:
https://disc.gsfc.nasa.gov/datasets/M2I3NXGAS_V5.12.4/summary?keywords=m2i3nxgas
If you follow the ‚ÄúOnline Archive‚Äù link it will lead you to the file downloads page for the collection:
https://goldsmr4.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/data/MERRA2/M2I3NXGAS.5.12.4/
And this service should work with wget.
I hope that‚Äôs what you were after.
Sincerely,
Nathan
PS -
The OPeNDAP servers are generally uutilized to transform the data response formats and to subset the data, in particular by allowing you to request as little as a single variable from a specific area. In your example collection, M2I3NXGAS, there are only a couple of range variables (AODANA & AODINC) and the domain is lat, lon, and time. However many of the files served at GES DISC contain hundreds of variables. So in general it is preferable from a cost of operations standpoint to subset when possible.

name.page: Downloading multiple MERR2 files using wget from the command line
name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Jen,
You can do that too, but that means the server is loading the file in to memory in a a very general data model and then rebuilding it as a netcdf4 file. It works, but is intended t be used in conjunction with a subsetting activity.
If you really want the files, please consider using the link I provided:
Actually, I see that some security thing on your end is destroying the URLs, which is regrettable I‚Äôll try again without the protocol prefix:
goldsmr4.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/data/MERRA2/M2I3NXGAS.5.12.4/
Hopefully you can add https a colon and two slashes to the beginning of that and it will be a much faster download for wget.

Greetings,
I am a grad student and trying to download JPL MEaSUREs Gridded Sea Surface Height Anomalies Version 1609 data for August 20th, 2005. I am at the OPeNDAP Server Dataset Access Form but do not understand how to select the data I require form the options presented. I tried to limit by longitude and latitude boundaries and time, but I get an error page. I browsed the data and selected the following limits: 284.167 to 255.167 for longitude and 34.1667 to 12.1667 for latitude and a date of 7506.5. I am trying to create a grid for the Gulf of Mexico on 08/20/2005. Is there a help document that explains how to select and download this data? Sherry Young
George Mason University
804-744-4716

name.page: Questions about how to select data
name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Sherry,
There are several different types of DAP server, each wih somewhat different capabilities.
All of the servers natively subset arrays by index and not by value. There is more about it here:
https://opendap.github.io/documentation/QuickStart.html#_an_easy_way_using_the_browser_based_opendap_server_dataset_access_form
If you are working with a Hyrax server the geogrid() function can be used to subset by value:
http://docs.opendap.org/index.php/Server_Side_Processing_Functions#geogrid.28.29
Hyrax can also return the result as a geotiff image. (Most of this is more effectively handled by direct manipulation of the request URL.)
If you send me the dataset URL I can provide more explicit examples.
Sincerely,
Nathan
However depending on the server implementation and the dataset (and I am offering a very general
- show quoted text -
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.page: Questions about how to select data
name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Sherry,
Have you tried opening the dataset URL directly in ArcMap?
I think that it may be able to talk to the server directly. Try looking around in the ArcMap UI to see if there is a place where it reads a NetCDF file or a remote resource. The underlying NetCDF library is smart and if you feed it this URL:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc
It may just ‚Äúwork‚Äù.
Or not, but before we do a bunch of harder work this is the place to start. (Note that the URL does not have to point to something that appears to be a NetCDF file as this one does, more that it points to a DAP server)
Let me know if you get anywhere with that!
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.page: Questions about how to select data
name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Sherry,
To bad ArcMap didn‚Äôt do it - it‚Äôs always nicer when things are easy.
To get a quick sense of the data I like to start at the catalog page. For this dataset I found it by truncating the URL to this:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/
You can also see (at the bottom of the page) that it is in fact a Hyrax server.
On that page you can see several links associated with the dataset. You can get a quick sense of the structure by looking at the DDS:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.dds
Which shows you how it‚Äôs represented:
Dataset {
Float32 Longitude[Longitude = 2160];
Float32 Lon_bounds[Longitude = 2160][nv = 2];
Float32 Latitude[Latitude = 960];
Float32 Lat_bounds[Latitude = 960][nv = 2];
Float32 Time_bounds[Time = 1][nv = 2];
Float32 Time[Time = 1];
Grid {
Array:
Float32 SLA_ERR[Time = 1][Longitude = 2160][Latitude = 960];
Maps:
Float32 Time[Time = 1];
Float32 Longitude[Longitude = 2160];
Float32 Latitude[Latitude = 960];
} SLA_ERR;
Grid {
Array:
Float32 SLA[Time = 1][Longitude = 2160][Latitude = 960];
Maps:
Float32 Time[Time = 1];
Float32 Longitude[Longitude = 2160];
Float32 Latitude[Latitude = 960];
} SLA;
} ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc;
This is an older version of Hyrax and I am afraid there is a problem with geogrid() - I was not able to get it to work.
Lacking a working geogrid() function I worked the issue using the ‚Äúmanual‚Äù method, tedious but doable. It‚Äôs far preferable to write a small shell script or python program to do the following for you.
To find the extents you‚Äôll have to inspect the Latitude and Longitude arrays to determine the indices of your bounding values. You wanted:
> 284.167 to 255.167 for longitude and 34.1667 to 12.1667 for latitude
It‚Äôs simple to get the server to return data as ascii values. This is done by modifying the URL, and then, since the data are large, restricting the request to return just the Longitude values (Note how I modified the dataset URL with the suffix ‚Äú.ascii‚Äù and then added a ‚Äú?" followed by the name of the longitude array ‚ÄúLongitude"
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude
But thats a bunch of points so we can look at a smaller ranges:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1520:1:1540]
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1720:1:1730]
Which I determined by estimation.
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1530]
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1729]
The closest longitude indices that include your desired interval are 1530 and 1729
So the longitude subset is:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Longitude[1530:1:1729]
Similarly we can determine the latitude bounds:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Latitude
Similarly, I poked at it until I got:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Latitude[552]
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Latitude[685]
So the latitude subset is:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?Latitude[552:1:685]
Now we can make the data request. You can use the data request form here:
https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.html
and select the SLA grid at the bottom and then insert the Longitude subset expression 1530:1:1729 and the Latitude subset expression 552:1:685 into the form and then use the buttons at the top to make the request.
Alternately you can do it by building the data request URLs as follows:
ASCII https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.ascii?SLA[0:1:0][1530:1:1729][552:1:685]
NetCDF-3 https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.nc?SLA[0:1:0][1530:1:1729][552:1:685]
NetCDF-4 https://podaac-opendap.jpl.nasa.gov/opendap/allData/merged_alt/L4/cdr_grid/ssh_grids_v1609_2005082012.nc.nc4?SLA[0:1:0][1530:1:1729][552:1:685]
And use those with a browser or the ‚Äúcurl‚Äù program from the command line.
If you have a large number of these to do I think you will be best served writing a small shell script or python program to do this for you!
I hope that helps‚Ä¶
Sincerely,
Nathan
> On Jan 17, 2018, at 1:48 PM, syoung20 <syou...@masonlive.gmu.edu> wrote:
>
> Hi Nathan,
>
> I tried to import the downloaded NetCDF file using the NetCDF to raster tool in ArcMap but it couldn't read it. Not sure where I'd enter a URL. Checking on that now.
>
> Sherry
> From: Nathan Potter <n...@opendap.org>
> Sent: Wednesday, January 17, 2018 5:44:52 PM
> To: syoung20
> Cc: Nathan Potter; OPENDAP support

Season's Greetings!

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Greetings,
The issue would appear to a problem with Matlab, or how you are using Matlab.
These URLs:
http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/thredds/dodsC/Datasets/ncep.reanalysis/surface_gauss/pres.sfc.gauss.2017.nc.dds
http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/thredds/dodsC/Datasets/ncep.reanalysis/surface_gauss/pres.sfc.gauss.2017.nc.das
http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/psd/thredds/dodsC/Datasets/ncep.reanalysis/surface_gauss/pres.sfc.gauss.2017.nc.asc?lat
All redirect to https and then return the expected response, which is a strong indication that the server is working correctly.
We have some simple directions for how to do this in Matlab here:
https://www.opendap.org/about/news/matlab-2012a-support
And we just tested this using matlab-2017b and it works great.
Please let me know how it goes!
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.name: ESRL/PSD Web & Data Management

apparently this was a problem at least through version 2016b. I've
had multiple reports now that version 2017b works, at least with the
HTTPS version of the URLs. I'm not certain any Matlab version
actually handles the re-direct if the HTTP versions are used.

name.name: Donna Johnson - NOAA Federal
name.body:
Hello
We were interested in extracting some data and wanted to know how to limit our output to within a specific geographic range. Is there anyway to input Lat and Lng coordinates?
Thanks very much.
~Donna

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Nov 9, 2017, at 12:22, Donna Johnson - NOAA Federal <donna....@noaa.gov> wrote:
Hello
We were interested in extracting some data and wanted to know how to limit our output to within a specific geographic range. Is there anyway to input Lat and Lng coordinates?
For data that show up as grids there is a way. Yo can use the geogrid() server function, which is documented here: https://opendap.github.io/hyrax_guide/Master_Hyrax_Guide.html#SSF_geogrid
Alternatively, you can look at the Latitude and Longitude vectors bound to the data and lookup the indices that correspond to the lat/lon values/range you want. Not as convenient as the geogrid() function, but can work in cases when the server function does not (i.e., when the dat appear as plain Arrays and not Grids).
James
Thanks very much.
~Donna
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Jonathan,
The server in question is operated by the good folks at NASA‚Äôa GESDISC and I am cc‚Äôing them so that they may be made aware of this issue.
Based on this error message:
"BES Client Failed To Start. Message: 'Could not connect to host localhost on port 10004. Connection refused (Connection refused)‚Äô‚Äù
It appears that one of the critical server components (known as the BES) is not currently running. Someone at GESDISC will be needed to restart it. Alternatively, it is possible that there is a problem with the server‚Äôs configuration, as the port number listed in the message is not the default port. This error could be evidence that a matching change was not made in other server components.
Regardless I am sure the folks at GESDISC will act quickly to correct the matter,
Thanks for your patience!
Sincerely,
Nathan

name.name: Kyle Cooper
name.body:
Good Afternoon
I've re-install OPeNDAP onto one of our production servers and I'm struggling with the what seem to be a simple problem of permissions issues. I have also a local test version of OPeNDAP that works successfully which implies this isn't my first rodeo, but I can seem to sort out this snag.
I have install OPeNDAP using the source install from the following documents from the wiki.
Once I config the setup and access the instance, I get the following:
‚Äã
But when I click on the ideal_dataset.nc I get the following response:
‚Äã
I get the following error in the tomcat log:
2017-12-07T09:47:41.584 +0200 [196.24.58.253] [Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/62.0.3202.94 Safari/537.36] [thread:http-nio-8080-exec-10] [63031263][22] [HTTP-GET] [/opendap/hyrax/ideal_dataset.nc.html] [] ERROR - opendap.coreServlet.OPeNDAPException - anyExceptionHandler(): opendap.bes.BESError: Permission denied
Having a understanding in using chown, and chmod I have tried every combination of user, group, and rwx, but I cannot seem to figure out the right combination. I even mirrored the permissions on my test OPenDAP instance on the production server, but does not work. My intention is for the tomcat user and group to run OPeNDAP. But
Is there an ideal setup for OPeNDAP for the permissions of users? So who should own the hyrax directory? Who should own the data directory? or am I just being silly with a simple sys admin issue?
Many Thanks
--
Kyle Cooper
Junior Systems Developer
Cell: +27 (0)73144 21045th Floor, Foretrust Building,
Martin Hammerschlag Way, CPTPrivate Bag X2, Roggebaai, 8012

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Dec 1, 2017, at 10:15 AM, Jonas Cavalcanti <jonascava...@gmail.com> wrote:
Hi James ,
My name is Jonas Cavalcanti, I am DevOps in government (FUNCEME - www.funceme.br). We
use ourselves Pydap 3.1.1, but need migrate of the physical server to Docker containers, so need reinstall all handlers. We use Pydap socker with command ( pydap --data /path/to/my/data/files --port 8080) but the protocol down when read big files. We thought about using Apache + WSGI + Pydap, but Pydap 3.1.1 with numpy latest dont read files (.ctl) which use cdms handler only .nc files. We think pydap 3.1.1 does not work with the latest version of numpy. I need to know how can I add the documentation of Apache2 + WSGI + Pydap in version 3.1.1.
I have not tested pydap 3.1.1 with the latest numpy - I‚Äôd check the list because I think your work will be much easier if they are compatible and pydap/numpy compatibility is the kind of thing that lots of people are likely to want, so you‚Äôll get help solving it.
I am not a regular user of pydap, so I‚Äôm less informed than the people on the pydap list.
James
Regards.

Jonas Cavalcanti

name.name: Unidata THREDDS Support
name.body:
Greetings Yi Dai,
There should not be any problems accessing the individual netCDF files via OPeNDAP.
The default binary response limit for the OPeNDAP server in the TDS is 500MB, but
this can be changed by the server admin.
Can you give us some more details about what happens when things do now work,
or, even better, the name of a dataset that does not work? Do you see an error
message?
Cheers,
Sean
> Greetings Yi Dai,
>
> The server in question is an instance of the THREDDS Data Server from
> Unidata (cc'd above) and operated by our friends at NOAA (also cc'd).
>
> Lacking the actual data access URLs that you are using I can only
> speculate about the issue. I do see a pretty noticeable fact, that the
> dataset is big.
>
> It contains 13 ~40MB variables:
>
> =
> https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/thredds/dodsC/cdr/gridsat/files/2014/GRIDSAT-B1.2014.09.16.06.v02r01.nc.dds
>
> The server in question undoubtably has limits as to the size of the
> requests that it can produce, and the problem you are encountering may
> simply mean that you have to make multiple requests using the server's
> subsetting features to reduce the size of the returned data for each
> request.
>
> =
> https://opendap.github.io/documentation/UserGuideComprehensive.html#Constraint_Expressions
>
> Which may be as simple as asking for one data variable at a time.
>
> Please let us know if you need additional assistance.
>
>
> Sincerely,
>
> Nathan
>
>
> > On Nov 6, 2017, at 9:24 AM, Dai, Yi <yd...@rsmas.miami.edu> wrote:
> >
> > Dear officer,
> >
> > I'm a graduate student at University of Miami. I tried to use some OPeNDAP
> > data (such as https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/thredds/dodsC/cdr/gridsat/files/2014/GRIDSAT-B1.2014.09.16.06.v02r01.nc). I used matlab 2017b to read the data.
> >
> > But this website is not very stable: it works for some timesteps, but
> > stops later. Is this a normal problem for using OPeNDAP data?
> >
> > Thanks,
> > Yi Dai
>
>
Ticket Details
===================
Ticket ID: JKC-446580
Department: Support THREDDS
Priority: Normal
Status: Open
===================
NOTE: All email exchanges with Unidata User Support are recorded in the Unidata inquiry tracking system and then made publicly available through the web. If you do not want to have your interactions made available in this way, you must let us know in each email you send to us.

name.name: Dai, Yi
name.body:
Hi Sean,
I think the problem is just that the website is not stable. When I tried the code today, it works perfectly. The data I tried to get is from the website: https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/thredds/catalog/cdr/gridsat/files/2014/catalog.html (an example). I read the data in a loop. At each step I only read a small amount of data, so the binary response limit might not be the reason of the problem. The error is that matlab (version 2017b) cannot read the 2-D field data (such as irwin_cdr), but be able to read 1-D data (such as lon and lat).
I searched online and found that some old version of matlab does not support (https) OPeNDAP data, so I updated to the newest version. Yes it can read (https) data, but still not stable.
Thanks,
Yi
From: Unidata THREDDS Support <support...@unidata.ucar.edu>
Sent: Tuesday, November 7, 2017 1:35:18 PM
To: Dai, Yi
Cc: n...@opendap.org; sup...@opendap.org; ncei...@noaa.gov
Subject: [Staging #JKC-446580]: unstable OPeNDAP server at NCEI
Greetings Yi Dai,
There should not be any problems accessing the individual netCDF files via OPeNDAP.
The default binary response limit for the OPeNDAP server in the TDS is 500MB, but
this can be changed by the server admin.
Can you give us some more details about what happens when things do now work,
or, even better, the name of a dataset that does not work? Do you see an error
message?
Cheers,
Sean
> Greetings Yi Dai,
>
> The server in question is an instance of the THREDDS Data Server from
> Unidata (cc'd above) and operated by our friends at NOAA (also cc'd).
>
> Lacking the actual data access URLs that you are using I can only
> speculate about the issue. I do see a pretty noticeable fact, that the
> dataset is big.
>
> It contains 13 ~40MB variables:
>
> =
> https://na01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncei.noaa.gov%2Fthredds%2FdodsC%2Fcdr%2Fgridsat%2Ffiles%2F2014%2FGRIDSAT-B1.2014.09.16.06.v02r01.nc.dds&data=02%7C01%7Cydai%40rsmas.miami.edu%7Cd75cd2aeb95d4e64453308d5260e4d66%7C2a144b72f23942d48c0e6f0f17c48e33%7C0%7C0%7C636456765230775999&sdata=pJyMGeSRSjuasb5MYN79pwJTo%2BZ0mBC6MIa1mTsFkFQ%3D&reserved=0
>
> The server in question undoubtably has limits as to the size of the
> requests that it can produce, and the problem you are encountering may
> simply mean that you have to make multiple requests using the server's
> subsetting features to reduce the size of the returned data for each
> request.
>
> =
> https://na01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fopendap.github.io%2Fdocumentation%2FUserGuideComprehensive.html%23Constraint_Expressions&data=02%7C01%7Cydai%40rsmas.miami.edu%7Cd75cd2aeb95d4e64453308d5260e4d66%7C2a144b72f23942d48c0e6f0f17c48e33%7C0%7C0%7C636456765230775999&sdata=bjvVap%2By4Nv0mNWpg%2BbvuLFZmhDYZIRhO9Wt46FL6mo%3D&reserved=0
>
> Which may be as simple as asking for one data variable at a time.
>
> Please let us know if you need additional assistance.
>
>
> Sincerely,
>
> Nathan
>
>
> > On Nov 6, 2017, at 9:24 AM, Dai, Yi <yd...@rsmas.miami.edu> wrote:
> >
> > Dear officer,
> >
> > I'm a graduate student at University of Miami. I tried to use some OPeNDAP
> > data (such as https://na01.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.ncei.noaa.gov%2Fthredds%2FdodsC%2Fcdr%2Fgridsat%2Ffiles%2F2014%2FGRIDSAT-B1.2014.09.16.06.v02r01.nc&data=02%7C01%7Cydai%40rsmas.miami.edu%7Cd75cd2aeb95d4e64453308d5260e4d66%7C2a144b72f23942d48c0e6f0f17c48e33%7C0%7C0%7C636456765230775999&sdata=IcFZ4B0qQB2zy4chRzkopxmXaVfQwWPeqg60iqyjTN8%3D&reserved=0). I used matlab 2017b to read the data.
> >

name.name: Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]
name.body:
Hi Nathan,
The versions are below. In the THREDDS catalog I originally referred to, there is also this line:
<thredds:dataset name="" ID="/opendap/hyrax/">
The empty ‚Äòname‚Äô in the ‚Äò<thredds:dataset/>‚Äô element seems to coexist with the wrong ‚ÄòID‚Äô in the child ‚Äò<thredds:catalogRef/>‚Äô. The value of the ‚Äòname‚Äô shall be ‚Äú/‚Äù. How is the ‚Äòname‚Äô formed?
CentOS 6.9
Tomcat 8
JVM Version: 1.8.0_151-b12
-Fan
- show quoted text -

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Fan,
I think the issue is a change in behavior between minor versions of Tomcat (I might be wrong, but please humor me), and so I need to know the actual version number, like 7.0.57 or 8.0.47 or 8.5.23. If you installed Tomcat using yum, it should tell you with a ‚Äúyum info tomcat‚Äù:
Installed Packages
Name : tomcat
Arch : noarch
Version : 7.0.77
Or something to that effect.
Thanks,
Nathan
- show quoted text -

name.name: Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]
name.body:
Hi Nathan,
I don‚Äôt mean to humor you but our SystemAdmin claims that we use the same tomcat to the minor version (7.0.82 below) on the two systems. Should they change their claim I‚Äôll let you know.
-Fan

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Fan,
I have an idea!
1) Please send me $CATALINA_HOME/conf/context.xml from both systems.
2) I‚Äôm thinking the problem might be a change in Tomcat - and I am not sure how it‚Äôs happening but you might want to read this ticket: https://opendap.atlassian.net/browse/HYRAX-361 And in particular read the comment I made today. In it there is a work around for the HYRAX-361 problem that involves changing the Tomcat configuration. I would love to find out if making that change to the Tomcat config on the goldsmr5 system causes a change in this problematic THREDDS catalog behavior.
Thanks,
Nathan
- show quoted text -

name.name: Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]
name.body:
Hi Nathan,
Thanks for the investigation. I am asking our system guy to add the attributes to the <context> element as you specified in the ticket for goldsmr5. I‚Äôll report back when I have a result.
I attach the two context.xml. They are the same, so it is still a puzzle why our goldsmr4 doesn‚Äôt have this behavior.
-Fan
- show quoted text -

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Thanks Fan! I‚Äôll be interested to see what happens with the configuration change.
- show quoted text -
> <goldsmr4_context.xml><goldsmr5_context.xml>
- show quoted text -

This fixed the problem on goldsmr5. Though it does not explain why our other servers work, I can live with it for now. Thanks for your hard work and quick turnaround!
-Fan

You can try to use GHRSS L4 foundation SST, such as MUR (https://podaac.jpl.nasa.gov/dataset/MUR-JPL-L4-GLOB-v4.1), OSTIA (https://podaac.jpl.nasa.gov/dataset/OSTIA-UKMO-L4-GLOB-v2.0), or CMC0.02 (https://podaac.jpl.nasa.gov/dataset/DMI_OI-DMI-L4-GLOB-v1.0) from PO.DAAC site, or climatology SST from NCEP (http://www.emc.ncep.noaa.gov/research/cmb/sst_analysis/).
Regards,
Wenhao Li

Website: http://podaac.jpl.nasa.gov

Ticket History
Sluleko Gwala 212532511 (Client) Posted On: 25 October 2017 11:50 AM
Sir/Madam
I am asking if you can help me with downloading AVHRR Monthly Sea Surface Temperature (SST) and climatology data for the year 2010, 2014,2015 and 2016. I have tried the pathfinder V 5.0 , V 5.1 and V 5.2. As you know, V5.0 and V5.1 provide data that span from 1981-2009 which include daily, monthly and annual data among others, while V5.2 do have data spanning from 2009-2016 but none of them indicate monthly SST measurements but instead only daily SST. Could you please direct me in the site where i can download Monthly AVHRR SST measurements please.
Respectfully,
Sluleko Gwala
Wen-Hao Li (Staff) Posted On: 25 October 2017 01:28 PM
Hi Sluleko,
Thank you for your inquiry.
Please review the stream of emails by following this link: https://podaac.jpl.nasa.gov/forum/viewtopic.php?f=6&t=20&p=143&hilit=avhrr#p143, you will find the answer. Let's know if you still have questions.
Regards,
Wenhao Li
---------------------------------------------------------

Email: pod...@podaac.jpl.nasa.gov
Website: http://podaac.jpl.nasa.gov
---------------------------------------------------------

name.name: Dai, Yi
name.body:
Dear officer,
I'm a graduate student at University of Miami. I tried to use some OPeNDAP data (such as https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/thredds/dodsC/cdr/gridsat/files/2014/GRIDSAT-B1.2014.09.16.06.v02r01.nc). I used matlab 2017b to read the data.
But this website is not very stable: it works for some timesteps, but stops later. Is this a normal problem for using OPeNDAP data?
Thanks,
Yi Dai

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Greetings Yi Dai,
The server in question is an instance of the THREDDS Data Server from Unidata (cc‚Äôd above) and operated by our friends at NOAA (also cc‚Äôd).
Lacking the actual data access URLs that you are using I can only speculate about the issue. I do see a pretty noticeable fact, that the dataset is big.
It contains 13 ~40MB variables:
https://www.ncei.noaa.gov/thredds/dodsC/cdr/gridsat/files/2014/GRIDSAT-B1.2014.09.16.06.v02r01.nc.dds
The server in question undoubtably has limits as to the size of the requests that it can produce, and the problem you are encountering may simply mean that you have to make multiple requests using the server's subsetting features to reduce the size of the returned data for each request.
https://opendap.github.io/documentation/UserGuideComprehensive.html#Constraint_Expressions
Which may be as simple as asking for one data variable at a time.
Please let us know if you need additional assistance.
Sincerely,
Nathan
- show quoted text -
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
James,
I should have taken a bit more time to explain my response - apologies for that.
We (OPeNDAP) are the developers of the data server software that ASDC and other NASA labs use to serve data. We don‚Äôt run any of these servers, but our support email address is embedded in the software as the default, so it‚Äôs often shown when error responses are returned (although this can be altered by a configuration parameter that‚Äôs pretty easy to change).
In this case ASDC is running the server and that‚Äôs why I forwarded your question to them. Most of the time these problems are power failures, OS update failures, et cetera. Of course, that doesn‚Äôt fix your problem, but hopefully they will get this ironed out soon.
If the problem persists, please let me know.
Thanks,
James

From: Kent Yang
Sent: Wednesday, June 14, 2017 5:14 PM
To: 'Friesz (CTR), Aaron'
Cc: James Gallagher
Subject: RE: OPeNDAP - Auto Scaling MODIS data
Hi Aaron,
This is exactly what I want to know. Thanks. So the millions range of LE and PLE with units of J/m^2/day are actually correct! We need to fix the HDF4 handler to handle this case correctly.
The rational for us to divide the scale_factor when scale_factor is >1, is that indeed MOD13A,13C and MOD09GA and maybe a bunch of others have the following scale and offset formula:
Final _data_value = (raw_data_value - offset)/scale
In general, the final data value is always scaled back from a bigger value to a smaller value. This is a special case we rarely encountered. Could you double check if there are similar cases in your data center that the handler applies the wrong scale and offset rule for MODIS products?
Thanks a lot for letting me know.
Kent
From: Friesz (CTR), Aaron [mailto:aaro...@usgs.gov]
Sent: Wednesday, June 14, 2017 4:17 PM
To: Kent Yang
Cc: James Gallagher
Subject: Re: OPeNDAP - Auto Scaling MODIS data
So we just confirmed with the product PI. The scale factors for ET and PET are both 0.1, while the scale factors for LE and PLE are both 10000. After the scale factor is applied to the LE and PLE variables, the data values fall in the millions range with units of units of J/m^2/day.
Some notes:
We have two OPeNDAP backends set up...one that's configured to scale data values and another that's configured to serve unscaled data.
Scaled OPeNDAP -> https://opendap.cr.usgs.gov/opendap/MOD16A2.006/h10v04.ncml.html
Unscaled OPeNDAP -> https://opendap.cr.usgs.gov/UNS_opendap/MOD16A2.006/h10v04.ncml.html
On the scaled OPeNDAP, the scale factor in the metadata for LE_500m and PLE_500m is 10000. This is the value I expect. When I request a NetCDF, 10000 is carried over as the scale factor for the LE and PLE layers. I think the NetCDF libraries used in python, HDFView, and Panoply auto-apply the scale factor incorrectly in this case, dividing the data by the scale factor rather than multiplying it. That's outside OPeNDAP. Inside OPeNDAP, when I request an ascii, it appears to be dividing the data by the scale factor rather than multiplying it as well.
On the unscaled OPeNDAP, you'll notice that the scale factor for LE_500m and PLE_500m is changed from 10000 to 9.999999747e-05. I would expect the scale factor to still be 10000. That incorrect scale factor gets carried over to the NetCDF outputs which will cause problem when applying the scale factor on those data. When you request an ascii output for the LE and PLE variables the returned data values are unscaled as expected.
Let me know if you need any more information.
Aaron
On Wed, Jun 14, 2017 at 1:35 PM, Kent Yang <mya...@hdfgroup.org> wrote:
Hi Aaron,
No problems. You are always welcome to ask me anything related to the Hyrax HDF handler issues.
For scale_factor = 10000, are you sure that the scale_factor equation should be data = scale_factor*data + add_offset
I can see the variable LE_500m and PLE_500m both have the original scale_factor = 10000.0. Could you verify the right value range of PLE_500m and PET_500m after the scale and offset are applied? LE_500 m is MODIS Gridded 500m 8-day Composite latent heat flux (LE) and the units is J/m^2/day
After I have a clearer understanding of the data, I can go back to you with a good explanation.
Kent
From: Friesz (CTR), Aaron [mailto:aaron.fr...@usgs.gov]
Sent: Wednesday, June 14, 2017 11:04 AM
To: Kent Yang
Cc: James Gallagher
Subject: OPeNDAP - Auto Scaling MODIS data
Hi Kent,
Sorry for all of the questions lately. It's one of the weeks I guess. We recently added a new MODIS product to OPeNDAP. Some of the variables have a scale factor of 0.1 and some of the variables have a scale factor of 10000. In all cases though, the data is unpacked using this equation:
data = scale_factor*data + add_offset
This equation seems to be what OPeNDAP uses to scale the data. However, for the variables with a scale factors of 10000, OPeNDAP seems to convert the value of 10000 to 0.0001 at some point. Here's a link to the MODIS product:
https://opendap.cr.usgs.gov/opendap/hyrax/MOD16A2.006/h10v04.ncml.html
In the variable metadata, 10000 is identified as the 'orig_scale_factor' for LE_500m. However, when I request an ascii of the data I get floating point values, and when I request a netcdf the scale_factor attribute is converted to 0.0001. Any insight would be great.
Thanks,
Aaron
--

name.page: Requesting help with freeform handler and line endings
name.name: Shannon Flynn
name.body:
Good morning all,
I hope you can help me understand the Freeform data handler a little better. I'm having trouble with line endings. I'm trying to get OPeNDAP to allow users to subset some ASCII data by using this handler. I'm not trying to convert the original data to another format.
As an example, I have this data file (same as https://ghrc.nsstc.nasa.gov/pub/fieldCampaigns/gpmValidation/iphex/disdrometers_and_gauges/rain_gauge_NASA/data/gauge/iphex_raingauge_NASA0045_A_20130919_20131229_gag.txt):
[10:04 AM user]$ head tester.txt
2013 IPHEx NASA0045_A MetOne 0.254 mm
Year Mon Day Jday Hr Min Sec Rain[mm] Lat Lon
2013 09 19 262 21 18 38 0.254 35.31534 -82.87200
2013 09 21 264 12 07 51 0.254 35.31536 -82.87196
2013 09 21 264 12 26 15 0.254 35.31536 -82.87196
2013 09 21 264 12 46 46 0.254 35.31536 -82.87196
2013 09 21 264 12 57 50 0.254 35.31536 -82.87196
2013 09 21 264 13 10 10 0.254 35.31536 -82.87196
2013 09 21 264 13 32 16 0.254 35.31536 -82.87196
2013 09 21 264 13 53 37 0.254 35.31536 -82.87196
First I made this format file, which has no end of line markup attempts:
ASCII_input_file_header "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge header"
year 1 4 short 0
field_program 6 10 char 0
gauge_id 12 21 char 0
gauge_type 23 28 char 0
bucket_resolution 30 34 float 3
bucket_units 36 37 char 0
labels 1 54 char 0
ASCII_input_data "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge"
year 1 4 short 0
month 7 8 uchar 0
day_of_month 11 12 uchar 0
day_of_year 15 17 short 0
hour 19 20 uchar 0
minute 23 24 uchar 0
second 27 28 uchar 0
rain_rate 31 35 float 3
latitude 38 45 float 5
longitude 48 56 float 5
This resulted in errors when I used chkform on it:
[10:07 AM user]$ chkform -d tester.txt -if tester.fmt -ol ol.log -el el.err
Welcome to Chkform release 4.2.3 -- an NGDC FreeForm ND application
Messages have been recorded in el.err
[10:07 AM user]$ cat el.err
There are 2 errors!
ERROR 1: Expecting an End-Of-Line marker
EXPLANATION: At position 55 in tester.txt ("gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge header")
ERROR 2: Setting data bin
EXPLANATION: getting header file for tester.txt
No more messages
So per http://docs.opendap.org/index.php/Wiki_Testing/tblfmt I attempted to use the EOL 'special' format descriptor via different incantations...first as a format descriptor with a variable:
[10:29 AM user]$ cat tester.fmt
ASCII_input_file_header "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge header"
year 1 4 short 0
field_program 6 10 char 0
gauge_id 12 21 char 0
gauge_type 23 28 char 0
bucket_resolution 30 34 float 3
bucket_units 36 37 char 0
labels 1 54 char 0
ASCII_input_file_header_RETURN "linebreak"
linebreak 55 56 char 0
ASCII_input_data "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge"
year 1 4 short 0
month 7 8 uchar 0
day_of_month 11 12 uchar 0
day_of_year 15 17 short 0
hour 19 20 uchar 0
minute 23 24 uchar 0
second 27 28 uchar 0
rain_rate 31 35 float 3
latitude 38 45 float 5
longitude 48 56 float 5
[10:30 AM user]$
Errors were:
There are 3 errors!
ERROR 1: Invalid parameter value
EXPLANATION: Bad number for variable start position: "linebreak"
ERROR 2: Problem with variable description line
EXPLANATION: ASCII_input_file_header_RETURN "linebreak"
ERROR 3: Setting data bin
EXPLANATION: setting an input format for tester.txt
Try #2, section 1.4.2 of http://docs.opendap.org/index.php/Wiki_Testing/tblfmt says I can use the "special" EOL/RETURN as a variable type, so:
[10:35 AM user]$ cat tester.fmt
ASCII_input_file_header "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge header"
year 1 4 short 0
field_program 6 10 char 0
gauge_id 12 21 char 0
gauge_type 23 28 char 0
bucket_resolution 30 34 float 3
bucket_units 36 37 char 0
labels 1 54 char 0
lineb 55 56 RETURN 0
ASCII_input_data "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge"
year 1 4 short 0
month 7 8 uchar 0
day_of_month 11 12 uchar 0
day_of_year 15 17 short 0
hour 19 20 uchar 0
minute 23 24 uchar 0
second 27 28 uchar 0
rain_rate 31 35 float 3
latitude 38 45 float 5
longitude 48 56 float 5
[10:35 AM user]$
Errors:
There are 3 errors!
ERROR 1: Unknown variable type
EXPLANATION: RETURN
ERROR 2: Problem with variable description line
EXPLANATION: lineb 55 56 RETURN
ERROR 3: Setting data bin
EXPLANATION: setting an input format for tester.txt
I didn't find any examples using EOL or RETURN or file/record headers at http://test.opendap.org/opendap/data/ff/contents.html .
I did find https://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/ecosys/cdroms/AVHRR97_d1/software/freeform/documnt/ffu31.pdf which gives an example of using RETURN at the top of page 53 (return line is also shown the same in http://docs.opendap.org/index.php/Wiki_Testing/hdrfmts), and so attempted:
[10:38 AM user]$ cat tester.fmt
ASCII_input_file_header "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge header"
year 1 4 short 0
field_program 6 10 char 0
gauge_id 12 21 char 0
gauge_type 23 28 char 0
bucket_resolution 30 34 float 3
bucket_units 36 37 char 0
labels 1 54 char 0
RETURN "NEW LINE INDICATOR"
ASCII_input_data "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge"
year 1 4 short 0
month 7 8 uchar 0
day_of_month 11 12 uchar 0
day_of_year 15 17 short 0
hour 19 20 uchar 0
minute 23 24 uchar 0
second 27 28 uchar 0
rain_rate 31 35 float 3
latitude 38 45 float 5
longitude 48 56 float 5
Resulting errors:
There are 3 errors!
ERROR 1: Invalid parameter value
EXPLANATION: Bad number for variable start position: "NEW LINE INDICATOR"
ERROR 2: Problem with variable description line
EXPLANATION: RETURN "NEW LINE INDICATOR"
ERROR 3: Setting data bin
EXPLANATION: setting an input format for tester.txt
Do any of you have some clues/insight/examples, etc., you could share that will steer me in the right direction?
Also, is anyone using this data handler "in the wild", or does everyone mostly just convert their data to other formats?
Thanks,
Shannon Flynn
ITSC/GHRC

name.page: Requesting help with freeform handler and line endings
name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
Shannon,
Here‚Äôs the correct format file - it took me a while because I‚Äôve never written one with two header lines.
ASCII_input_file_header "gpmrgnaiphx2 gauge header"
year 1 4 short 0
field_program 6 10 char 0
gauge_id 12 21 char 0
gauge_type 23 28 char 0
bucket_resolution 30 34 float 3
bucket_units 36 37 char 0
column_labels 38 92 char 0
ASCII_input_data "gpmrgnaiphx2_gauge"
year 1 4 short 0
month 7 8 uchar 0
day_of_month 11 12 uchar 0
day_of_year 15 17 short 0
hour 19 20 uchar 0
minute 23 24 uchar 0
second 27 28 uchar 0
rain_rate 31 35 float 3
latitude 38 45 float 5
longitude 48 56 float 5
The trick is to read the new line (or return) character at the end of the first line of the header and include it in the next variable (see ‚Äòcolumn_labels‚Äô in the above ASCII_input_file_header).
Also note that I used an underscore in the ASCII_input_data name - this works better since DAP treats spaces as word separators and thus the space would make writing constraints harder.
If this does not work for you, let me know!
James
On Oct 31, 2017, at 09:51, Shannon Flynn <sef...@uah.edu> wrote:
- show quoted text -
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.body: Thank you James, this seems to be working!

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Hubert,
By default the server does not allow direct access to (i.e. downloads of) files that it considers ‚Äúdata‚Äù.
You can allow this access but changing the configuration of the OLFS.
The Prolog:
If you have done so yet, you will need to set up a local configuration for the OLFS.
This can be quickly accomplished by:
1) Creating the directory /etc/olfs and making it readable and writable
by the user that is running your Tomcat instance.
2) Restart Tomcat
On startup the OLFS will detect this new directory and copy the default configuration to it.
The Fix:
Edit the file /etc/olfs/olfs.xml
Locate this line (~line 125):
<!-- AllowDirectDataSourceAccess / ‚Äî>
And uncomment it is that it reads:
<AllowDirectDataSourceAccess />
Restart Tomcat and you should be good to go.
Sincerely,
Nathan
> On Oct 30, 2017, at 7:57 PM, Huber Gilt Lopez <hg...@igp.gob.pe> wrote:
>
> Hello Nathan
>
> How can I disable this message?
>
> The requested URL directly references a data source.
>
> You must use the OPeNDAP request interface to get data from the data source.
>
> Hyrax : Access Denied (403)
>
> Best regards
>
> Huber
>
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]
name.body:
We have this setting in bes.conf:
BES.LogVerbose=no
However our system admins complained that there was still too much logging in bes.log. They claimed that a ‚ÄúNot Found‚Äù error created 5 lines of log such as:
|&|GMT Mon Oct 30 13:47:53 2017|&|pid: 61695|&|beslistener: BES Not Found Error
|&|GMT Mon Oct 30 13:47:53 2017|&|pid: 61646|&|ip 127.0.0.1, port 51890|&|request received|&|
|&|GMT Mon Oct 30 13:47:53 2017|&|pid: 61646|&|ip 127.0.0.1, port 51890|&|set context bes_timeout to 300;|&|request received|&|
|&|GMT Mon Oct 30 13:47:53 2017|&|pid: 61646|&|ip 127.0.0.1, port 51890|&|set context errors to xml;|&|request received|&|
|&|GMT Mon Oct 30 13:47:53 2017|&|pid: 61646|&|ip 127.0.0.1, port 51890|&|show catalog for GPM_L3/GPM_3IMERGHHL.03/2015/181/;|&|request received|&|
and a success can generate upward of 50 lines.
Can the log be further reduced by a ‚Äòno‚Äô setting of the LogVerbose?
-Fan

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
- show quoted text -
Funny, I was just looking at that. We are in the process of making those logs more concise.
My understanding is that NASA‚Äôs SAs requested the logs use ‚Äò|&|‚Äô as a separator, is that correct? Also, do we need the leading separator?
Regarding what _is_ logged: Would a standard (not verbose) log have one line per request? So for the above 'show catalog ‚Ä¶‚Äô request, there would be just one line saying something like:
|&|GMT Mon Oct 30 13:47:53 2017|&|pid: 61646|&|ip 127.0.0.1, port 51890|&|show catalog for GPM_L3/GPM_3IMERGHHL.03/2015/181/;|&|request received|&|
Or more concisely:
GMT Mon Oct 30 13:47:53 2017|&|61646|&|127.0.0.1: 51890|&|show catalog for GPM_L3/GPM_3IMERGHHL.03/2015/181/;
We can do this and get it in 1.14.1, just let me know.
James
-Fan
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

Hi James,
I don‚Äôt recall I requested ‚Äò|&|‚Äô as the separator in bes.log. It could be from someone else at NASA. We are ok if keeping the separator, including the leading one. Reducing the log to one (or two) line per request in ‚ÄòBES.LogVerbose=no‚Äô setting would be great, as long as it can indicate an error if any. Thanks.
-Fan
