name.name: Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]
name.body:
Hi. It seems that ‚Äò/etc/logrotate.d‚Äô in the release 1.13.4 RPM restarts bes and tomcat every day. This would be fine if we had not other processes relying on tomcat but has since caused troubles to these processes. In a few cases the bes failed to restart also.
This is at least in conflict with our own processes that truncates and backup the previous day‚Äôs log, which do not require restarting the server. Can we adopt a similar practice in Hyrax, or at least a less brute-force one?
-Fan

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Aug 29, 2017, at 09:22, Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC] <fan.f...@nasa.gov> wrote:
Hi. It seems that ‚Äò/etc/logrotate.d‚Äô in the release 1.13.4 RPM restarts bes and tomcat every day. This would be fine if we had not other processes relying on tomcat but has since caused troubles to these processes. In a few cases the bes failed to restart also.
This is at least in conflict with our own processes that truncates and backup the previous day‚Äôs log, which do not require restarting the server. Can we adopt a similar practice in Hyrax, or at least a less brute-force one?
Sure. (Sorry for the long delay in responding)
Can you send me the logrotate code/setting you are using?
James
-Fan
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.name: Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]
name.body:
Hi James,
Sorry for the late response. I have below a logrotate setting that we use on a typical server. Let me know if you need more info.
-Fan
cat /etc/logrotate.d/bes
/var/log/bes/bes.log {
weekly
rotate 26
create 0644 bes bes
missingok
notifempty
copytruncate
compress
}
cat /etc/logrotate.conf
# see "man logrotate" for details
# rotate log files weekly
weekly
# keep 52 weeks worth of backlogs
rotate 52
# create new (empty) log files after rotating old ones
create
# use date as a suffix of the rotated file
dateext
# default directory to rotate old logs into
olddir /var/log/old/
# uncomment this if you want your log files compressed
#compress
# RPM packages drop log rotation information into this directory
include /etc/logrotate.d
# no packages own wtmp and btmp -- we'll rotate them here
/var/log/wtmp {
monthly
create 0664 root utmp
#minsize 1M
compress
rotate 12
}
/var/log/btmp {
missingok
monthly
create 0600 root utmp
rotate 12
}
# system-specific logs may be also be configured here.
From: James Gallagher <jgall...@opendap.org>
Date: Monday, October 16, 2017 at 11:49 AM
To: "Fang, Fan (GSFC-610.2)[ADNET SYSTEMS INC]" <fan.f...@nasa.gov>
Cc: James Gallagher <jgall...@opendap.org>, "sup...@opendap.org" <sup...@opendap.org>
Subject: Re: [support] logrotate practice
- show quoted text -
--
James Gallagher
jgallagher@opendap.org

name.name: Kent Yang
name.body:
Hi Matthew,
Could you point to me where I can download the HDF-EOS5 file? The CF option only supports two HDF-EOS5 projections: geographic and sinusoidal projections? I am planning to support more projections. Kent

name.name: Aron Bartle
name.body:
Hello Nathan & James, hope all is well.
A colleague at the data center and I were wondering if there is any way to run BES not as root?
Walt is trying to deploy on a type of auto-scaling system where the policy disallows any process to be executed as root.
I see that besdaemon changes to user "bes" after its started, but presumably they won't go for that because it still started as root.
What I don't know is why besdaemon needs to run as root at startup... could it detect the current user is the same as "BES.user" and allow execution?
Thanks,
-Aron

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:

Thanks,
-Aron

James Gallagher

name.page: Question about retrieval of TopoWx data via OpenDAP
name.name: Michael Treglia
name.body:
Hi,
Hi, my name is Mike Treglia, and I work with The Nature Conservancy‚Äôs NYC Program. I have been working to retrieve spatial and temporal subsets of the TopoWx data via OpenDAP, and it seems when I‚Äôm requesting data a large number of time points, the request hangs up. I just figured I‚Äôd see if there is a limit from OpenDAP on the number of requests within a period of time or anything similar.
If it helps, I‚Äôm doing this in R, with sample code here: https://gist.github.com/mtreg/e86c516a4ace3ec54e8bd36bcd9da875 - this works great with up time periods extending about 30 days (not sure what the max limit is that I reach), but when I try for ~150 days, for example, I get a NetCDF I/O Failure error in R. (Note: The R netcdf dependencies are best run on MacOS or Linux, as they are not compiled for Windows to access OpenDAP)
Thus, I can certainly batch the data calls, but would like to do so for the largest number of requests possible. And if it‚Äôs not a limit on the OpenDAP side, that would be great to know too.
Thanks so much for any support on this issue.
Best regards,
Mike
Please consider the environment before printing this email.

name.page: Question about retrieval of TopoWx data via OpenDAP
name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Mike,
That is an instance of the THREDDS Data Server (aka the TDS: http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/http://www.unidata.ucar.edu/software/thredds/current/tds//thredds/current/tds/ ) which implements the OPeNDAP protocol. I believe that it does have response size limitations and that what you may have to do is craft requests that subset the data on the server's end.
Things to try:
- Reducing the spatial area by subsetting the requested arrays.
- Iterating over time points/periods to incrementally retrieve the entire series.
Does that make sense?
Sincerely,
Nathan
> On Sep 19, 2017, at 8:29 AM, Michael Treglia <michael...@TNC.ORG> wrote:
>
> Ni Nathan,
>
> Thanks for the quick response! The URL I‚Äôm calling from is here: https://cida.usgs.gov/thredds/dodsC/topowx.html (in the R code the html gets left off).
>
> Best,
> Mike
>
> Please consider the environment before printing this email.
> ‚Äã
- show quoted text -

name.page: Question about retrieval of TopoWx data via OpenDAP
name.name: David Blodgett
name.body:
Hi Michael,
I would guess you are hitting the THREDDS/OPeNDAP single request size limit, but it may be something network related.
I would suggest chunking in time based on a single request taking no more than about 10 seconds to complete. Don't worry about sending lots of requests if you need to. Our THREDDS server can handle lots of small requests if need be.
- Dave
Note the opendap.org folks probably don't need to worry about this since we are running THREDDS.
On Sep 19, 2017, at 9:21 AM, Michael Treglia <michael...@TNC.ORG> wrote:
Hi,
Hi, my name is Mike Treglia, and I work with The Nature Conservancy‚Äôs NYC Program. I have been working to retrieve spatial and temporal subsets of the TopoWx data via OpenDAP, and it seems when I‚Äôm requesting data a large number of time points, the request hangs up. I just figured I‚Äôd see if there is a limit from OpenDAP on the number of requests within a period of time or anything similar.
If it helps, I‚Äôm doing this in R, with sample code here: https://gist.github.com/mtreg/e86c516a4ace3ec54e8bd36bcd9da875 - this works great with up time periods extending about 30 days (not sure what the max limit is that I reach), but when I try for ~150 days, for example, I get a NetCDF I/O Failure error in R. (Note: The R netcdf dependencies are best run on MacOS or Linux, as they are not compiled for Windows to access OpenDAP)
Thus, I can certainly batch the data calls, but would like to do so for the largest number of requests possible. And if it‚Äôs not a limit on the OpenDAP side, that would be great to know too.
Thanks so much for any support on this issue.
Best regards,
Mike
Please consider the environment before printing this email.

Subject: Re: Question about retrieval of TopoWx data via OpenDAP
Hi Michael,
I would guess you are hitting the THREDDS/OPeNDAP single request size limit, but it may be something network related.
I would suggest chunking in time based on a single request taking no more than about 10 seconds to complete. Don't worry about sending lots of requests if you need to. Our THREDDS server can handle lots of small requests if need be.
- Dave
Note the opendap.org folks probably don't need to worry about this since we are running THREDDS.

name.name: Gareth....@csiro.au
name.body:
Greetings.
I‚Äôve returned to updating our OPeNDAP setup in CSIRO, intending to use a dockerised deployment and found that you‚Äôve made great progress https://github.com/OPENDAP/hyrax-docker and published containers on docker hub https://hub.docker.com/r/opendap/hyrax_ncwms/ (also without ncwms). Congratulations!
The containers work nicely for me so far and I have some feedback that I can summarise here in point form. Possibly some can be converted into issues for either the hyrax-docker project or the upstream software component projects. I‚Äôll conform to whatever suits you best and potentially fork hyrax-docker and submit changes back as pull requests.
Points follow:
. I see tomcat is run by root in opendap/hyrax_ncwms ‚Äì that should probably be changed
. I‚Äôll be looking for how to tune java ‚Äì not asking just yet but making a note‚Ä¶ Perhaps I need to inject a javaopts.sh
. ncWMS performance has been slow for me. I‚Äôd value help
. I have some experience with the travis-ci github integration as done in thredds-docker ‚Äì I‚Äôd recommend adding that to the project
. Do you plan to release separate besd, olfs and ncWMS images on dockerhub? ‚Äì I guess I‚Äôd prefer to compose them ‚Äì but the combined image is nice too (I should probably move to building/testing myself and using my own registry for blessed images but I‚Äôm not quite there yet).
. Where does the custom help email (SERVER_HELP_EMAIL) get published? I see my customization hits /etc/bes/bes.conf but can‚Äôt see it in the presented web pages anywhere.
Regards,
Gareth Williams
CSIRO IMT Scientific Computing Services
Private Bag 10
Clayton South Vic 3170

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
> On Aug 30, 2017, at 11:15 PM, <Gareth.Williams@csiro.au> <Gareth.Williams@csiro.au> wrote:
>
> Greetings.
>
> I‚Äôve returned to updating our OPeNDAP setup in CSIRO, intending to use a dockerised deployment and found that you‚Äôve made great progresshttps://github.com/OPENDAP/hyrax-docker and published containers on docker hub https://hub.docker.com/r/opendap/hyrax_ncwms/ (also without ncwms). Congratulations!
>
> The containers work nicely for me so far and I have some feedback that I can summarise here in point form. Possibly some can be converted into issues for either the hyrax-docker project or the upstream software component projects. I‚Äôll conform to whatever suits you best and potentially fork hyrax-docker and submit changes back as pull requests.
>
> Points follow:
>
> . I see tomcat is run by root in opendap/hyrax_ncwms ‚Äì that should probably be changed
I tried, but gave up in frustration. It seems the nuances of getting multiple users configured in Docker land has so far escaped me. The Hyrax combined image requires the root user to launch the BES. And, as you pointed out, a different, less privileged user, to run Tomcat. Now it is of interest that although the Tomcat in the combined image is a YUM installed Tomcat from some CentOS YUM repo none of the system ‚Äúservice‚Äù stuff is available so I was unable to launch using:
service tomcat start;
And had to utilize a direct invocation of Tomcat:
/usr/libexec/tomcat/server start > /var/log/tomcat/console.log 2>&1 &
Which runs it as root. There is a ‚Äútomcat‚Äù user:
[-bash: ~] docker exec --user tomcat hyrax_container whom
tomcat
However, if in the the startup script ‚Äúentry_point.sh‚Äù, I try this:
su tomcat /usr/libexec/tomcat/server start > /var/log/tomcat/console.log 2>&1 &
It generates the error: "This account is currently not available.‚Äù
Which seems right because the tomcat user has a nologin shell in /etc/passwd:
tomcat:x:91:91:Apache Tomcat:/usr/share/tomcat:/sbin/nologin
And I am not inclined to change the tomcat user to one with a login shell‚Ä¶
Thoughts?
I also tried using the UNIDATA ‚Äúsecure‚Äù Tomcat (which looks a lot like a simple YUM installed Tomcat run in secure mode) but they have moved to Tomcat 8.5+ and somewhere between 8.32 and now Tomcat updated the default rules for security manager and now neither the OLFS or ncWMS are able to run when Tomcat is in secure mode: Both applications utilize calls to System.getProperty() which is now verboten. In order for the OLFS and ncWMS to run in secured Tomcat we will need to develop the appropriate permissions entries and poke them into $CATALINA_BASE/conf/catalina.policy during the build.
>
> . I‚Äôll be looking for how to tune java ‚Äì not asking just yet but making a note‚Ä¶ Perhaps I need to inject a javaopts.sh
I have not looked into this at all so I don‚Äôt have much to say here beyond that we should do it and make it easy :) Probably something we could add to the ‚Äúlocal.env‚Äù (a.k.a. a localized version of hyrax_docker/hyrax-1.13.5/local.env.orig) which is already employed by the docker-compose stuff‚Ä¶
>
> . ncWMS performance has been slow for me. I‚Äôd value help
Can you tell me more? I‚Äôm not sure how to help‚Ä¶
It may be resource starved (see previous point) but beyond that I‚Äôm not sure what to suggest.
>
> . I have some experience with the travis-ci github integration as done in thredds-docker ‚Äì I‚Äôd recommend adding that to the project
We would like that too, but time/$$/time/$$ and all that‚Ä¶ Pull request?
Note: If it matters w.r.t. Travis, my plan is to organize the hyrax-docker project and published images the way Tomcat does
https://hub.docker.com/r/_/tomcat/
https://github.com/docker-library/tomcat
>
> . Do you plan to release separate besd, olfs and ncWMS images on dockerhub? ‚Äì I guess I‚Äôd prefer to compose them ‚Äì but the combined image is nice too (I should probably move to building/testing myself and using my own registry for blessed images but I‚Äôm not quite there yet).
We discussed this, but for the moment are leaving the building of the these images as an exercise for the user :)
We are not opposed to publishing them, again a question of time/$$/time/$$...
For now they should build easily from:
https://github.com/OPENDAP/hyrax-docker/tree/master/hyrax-1.13.5/olfs
https://github.com/OPENDAP/hyrax-docker/tree/master/hyrax-1.13.5/bes
https://github.com/OPENDAP/hyrax-docker/tree/master/hyrax-1.13.5/ncWMS
And there are example YML files here:
https://github.com/OPENDAP/hyrax-docker/tree/master/hyrax-1.13.5
>
> . Where does the custom help email (SERVER_HELP_EMAIL) get published? I see my customization hits /etc/bes/bes.conf but can‚Äôt see it in the presented web pages anywhere.
That‚Äôs good! Seriously - That address gets returned in error messages and error pages so if you aren‚Äôt seeing it that‚Äôs a good thing. Try asking the server for something it doesn‚Äôt have - you should see the address at the end of the 404 page.
Sincerely,
Nathan
>
> Regards,
>
> Gareth Williams
> CSIRO IMT Scientific Computing Services
> Private Bag 10
> Clayton South Vic 3170
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: Gareth....@csiro.au
name.body:
Thanks Nathan.
It is late here and I'll just respond on root and services.
A school of thought (a good one I think) says docker containers are for microservices with one per container and no init/service setup. Each container should just run one process (pid=1!) in the foreground, preferably not as root. It is not a full VM - that is part of the benefit, with a smaller range of vulnerabilities. This does not suit some software but bes and tomcat run fine in a foreground mode so can match well. Having the multi-component hyrax container breaks this ideal but it doesn't really matter (and simplifies things in one way, but requiring backgrounding and sleep loop and so on).
Setting the user is a bit tricky, especially if you have an entrypoint that needs to do some things as root then drop to non-root. There are a number of non-su options available - one is gosu https://github.com/tianon/gosu - and there are many docker projects that use it. It should be easy enough to incorporate it to run tomcat as user tomcat.
Regards,
Gareth
- show quoted text -

name.name: gaj...@gmail.com
name.body:
following up - I found that setting JAVA_OPTS in the environment (in docker run options) is picked up by tomcat. It would be nice if tuning java was more than guess-work. Do you know how I might determine if too little or too much memory is being used? I'm currently passing: JAVA_OPTS="-Djava.security.egd=file:/dev/urandom -Djava.awt.headless=true -Xms2G -Xms128m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC" Probably not all of that is useful.
This (probably just the 2G) has helped to avoid an issue where selecting the 'viewers' link gives an empty response in some cases. This seems to be repeatable with some of the testdata nc content (and the current opendap/hyrax_ncwms:latest from docker hub
My test setup is not publicly visible but the URLs are like: http://hyrax.csiro.au/opendap/viewers/viewers?dapService=/opendap/hyrax&datasetID=/test-data/nc/coads_climatology.nc as presented on http://hyrax.csiro.au/opendap/test-data/nc/contents.html (That site works fine but also has slow wms. it is the site I'm working on replacing).
The 'empty' response yields 200 and <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
No errors are logged - but the request is logged and the bes logs making a ddx response.
I'll submit an issue to hyrax-docker regarding tuning java when ncwms is wanted.
The java 'tuning' has helped with the wms performance - I think I'll go and assign more memory to the old setup now!
regards,
Gareth

name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Sep 8, 2017, at 01:16, gaj...@gmail.com wrote:
following up - I found that setting JAVA_OPTS in the environment (in docker run options) is picked up by tomcat. It would be nice if tuning java was more than guess-work. Do you know how I might determine if too little or too much memory is being used? I'm currently passing: JAVA_OPTS="-Djava.security.egd=file:/dev/urandom -Djava.awt.headless=true -Xms2G -Xms128m -XX:+UseConcMarkSweepGC" Probably not all of that is useful.
Looking into these options a bit I found (and I‚Äôm summarizing these to make a record, because I didn‚Äôt know about them):
_-Djava.security.egd=file:/dev/urandom_ is a way to speed up some security -related operations. See the info below. You probably know that weak randomness is one (of the best?) way to break encryption, but the crypto might not be that important.
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/137212/how-to-solve-slow-java-securerandom
You should be able to select the faster-but-slightly-less-secure /dev/urandom on Linux using:
-Djava.security.egd=file:/dev/urandom
However, this doesn't work with Java 5 and later (Java Bug 6202721). The suggested work-around is to use:
-Djava.security.egd=file:/dev/./urandom
(note the extra /./)
For _java.awt.headless=true_
Headless mode is a system configuration in which the display device, keyboard, or mouse is lacking. Sounds unexpected, but actually you can perform different operations in this mode, even with graphic data.
Where it is applicable? Let's say that your application repeatedly generates a certain image, for example, a graphical authorization code that must be changed every time a user logs in to the system. When creating an image, your application needs neither the display nor the keyboard. Let's assume now that you have a mainframe or dedicated server on your project that has no display device, keyboard, or mouse. The ideal decision is to use this environment's substantial computing power for the visual as well as the nonvisual features. An image that was generated in the headless mode system then can be passed to the headful system for further rendering.
_UseConcMarkSweepGC_ There‚Äôs lots of talk about garbage collection. Always has been‚Ä¶ But this option combines two techniques that (seem) to make good use of parallelism.
See http://www.fasterj.com/articles/oraclecollectors1.shtml and generally Google about it.
This (probably just the 2G) has helped to avoid an issue where selecting the 'viewers' link gives an empty response in some cases. This seems to be repeatable with some of the testdata nc content (and the current opendap/hyrax_ncwms:latest from docker hub
My test setup is not publicly visible but the URLs are like: http://hyrax.csiro.au/opendap/viewers/viewers?dapService=/opendap/hyrax&datasetID=/test-data/nc/coads_climatology.nc as presented on http://hyrax.csiro.au/opendap/test-data/nc/contents.html (That site works fine but also has slow wms. it is the site I'm working on replacing).
The 'empty' response yields 200 and <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
No errors are logged - but the request is logged and the bes logs making a ddx response.
I'll submit an issue to hyrax-docker regarding tuning java when ncwms is wanted.
Great. Thanks.
I think you‚Äôre right, it‚Äôs probably the memory size that makes the most difference. I would be cautious about the weaker randomness.
James
The java 'tuning' has helped with the wms performance - I think I'll go and assign more memory to the old setup now!
regards,
Gareth
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.name: gaj...@gmail.com
name.body:
Thanks James,
I think I took most of the options from previous recommendations or 'discoveries' - mostly from working with TDS/thredds. Some may be defaults - but defaults may change over time. It always seems tricky to decide when to be explicit (And think you help to control stability) and when to only specify what you need (and hope to get incidental improvements for free, and test for and/or hope not to get bitten by troublesome upstream default changes).
With the current thredds-docker using /dev/urandom made a major startup time difference. It did not need /dev/./urandom - that may not apply to openjdk. I've not actually had startup time problems with hyrax and probably should have left that out of my post - but there was some point in noting that this is a generic method for passing java options.
Regarding security, there is very mixed advice on the current merits or random vs urandom. I think in my case it doesn't matter but can appreciate the need to be cautious in general and specifically when giving general advice on an open forum.
Mostly I wanted to share what I'd learned and to get documentation improvements into hyrax-docker - the containerization offers a nest way of delivering environment customization alongside specific software. Documenting use of java options 'as code' would be a valuable improvement.
Gareth
- show quoted text -

name.name: Gareth....@csiro.au
name.body:
+ Agree. Thanks for send that info along.
+ Are you going to fork our hyrax-docker repo and work with it?
+ James
I have no immediate plans to fork. It is working sufficiently for me as is and I can maintain my own environment customizations. It would be good to have the documentation/guidance updated for others but I don‚Äôt think there is particular value in me forking just for that.
Perhaps add text like:
If JAVA_OPTS is defined in the container runtime environment, tomcat/olfs/ncWMS will include those options in the service start up. There are many options that could be passed. Of particular note is ‚ÄìXmx which sets the amount of memory available. ncWMS will not work properly with low memory limits. JAVA_OPTS can be set by normal methods: on the docker run command line, or in docker-compose configuration or in your own container layer if you build on the provided containers.
Sorry I‚Äôve not been very precise in that test but hopefully it is a good start.
You might also add an env setting to the Dockerfile(s) as implicit embedded documentation that the JAVA_OPTS setting is useful and expected to be tuned.
Gareth

name.page: Developer documentation for writing data handlers
name.name: Chris Piker
name.body:
Hi OPeNDAP
I have an in-house data system (das2.org) for streaming planetary
magnetosphere data sets that is based off of small server side programs
which supply time-reduced data streams. It's primarily used to
provide variable-resolution datasets to Autoplot. (http://autoplot.org)
I'm pondering upgrades to my current system and see no reason to invent
yet another data server if I don't have to. The Hyrax server looks
interesting and I am wondering what kind of glue code I would need to
write in order to re-use my reader programs as a back end for Hyrax.
Also, have you ever kicked around providing a simple multi-server
catalog service to allow for easier collaboration across groups, or
is that far the scope of OPeNDAP ?
Thanks!
--
Chris Piker

name.page: Developer documentation for writing data handlers
name.name: jgallagher
name.body:
On Aug 18, 2017, at 00:45, Chris Piker <chris...@uiowa.edu> wrote:
Hi OPeNDAP
I have an in-house data system (das2.org) for streaming planetary
magnetosphere data sets that is based off of small server side programs
which supply time-reduced data streams. It's primarily used to
provide variable-resolution datasets to Autoplot. (http://autoplot.org)
I'm pondering upgrades to my current system and see no reason to invent
yet another data server if I don't have to. The Hyrax server looks
interesting and I am wondering what kind of glue code I would need to
write in order to re-use my reader programs as a back end for Hyrax.
Sorry for the delay in getting back to you‚Ä¶
It really depends on the way you‚Äôre storing the data now. Generally, it would be C++ code, but not very hard code. You‚Äôd need to fill in values in a C++ object and the server takes care of the rest. Until you get to reading actual values, then you‚Äôll need to provide a handful of methods.
Let us know a bit more about your data and it‚Äôs existing access tools and we‚Äôll help you out.
Also, have you ever kicked around providing a simple multi-server
catalog service to allow for easier collaboration across groups, or
is that far the scope of OPeNDAP ?
We have, but so far it‚Äôs been out of scope. It would be possible to write THREDDS catalog files for several servers and host them on some HTTPd.
Nathan, can you chime in? Am I way off base here?
James
Thanks!
--
Chris Piker
--
James Gallagher
jgall...@opendap.org

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Bailey,
In my browser the URL you provided fails because it attempts to download the underlying HDF file and that access is disabled on the server.
What software did you use to access this URL, a browser? Or something else?
If you provide a DAP protocol suffix to the URL, for example ‚Äú.dds‚Äù, you should get back a response. Here‚Äôs a curl example:
curl "https://disc2.gesdisc.eosdis.nasa.gov/opendap/TRMM_L3/TRMM_3B43/1998/3B43.19980101.7.HDF.dds?precipitation%5B0:1:1439%5D%5B0:1:399%5D,relativeError%5B0:1:1439%5D%5B0:1:399%5D,gaugeRelativeWeighting%5B0:1:1439%5D%5B0:1:399%5D,nlon%5B0:1:1439%5D,nlat%5B0:1:399%5D"
Dataset {
Float32 precipitation[nlon = 1440][nlat = 400];
Float32 relativeError[nlon = 1440][nlat = 400];
Int32 gaugeRelativeWeighting[nlon = 1440][nlat = 400];
Float32 nlon[nlon = 1440];
Float32 nlat[nlat = 400];
} 3B43.19980101.7.HDF;
Note the suffix ‚Äú.dds‚Äù applied to the end if the URL path, just before the question mark. Also - to use curl you have to follow the configuration steps detailed here:
http://docs.opendap.org/index.php/DAP_Clients_-_Authentication
If that doesn‚Äôt work then something may be going on with your credentials or your ‚ÄúApproved Applications‚Äù in Earthdata Login.
You can specify how you want the data returned by changing the URL path suffix:
.dds - Syntactic Metadata (See above example)
.das - Semantic Metadata
.dods - DAP2 Binary Response
.nc - Netcdf-3
.nc4 - Netcdf-4
There are more formats available if none of these suit you.
Sincerely,
Nathan
- show quoted text -
= = =
Nathan Potter ndp at opendap.org
OPeNDAP, Inc. +1.541.231.3317

name.name: Nathan Potter
name.body:
Hi Bailey,
I think the issue is that you have not yet "authorized the application‚Äù. In this context what that means is that you have to login to your Earthdata Login account using a browser and specifically permit this data service: "NASA GESDISC DATA ARCHIVE‚Äù to access your login profile. Really. It‚Äôs a thing.
What you do:
With your browser:
- Go here: https://urs.earthdata.nasa.gov/profile
- Click the link/tab called ‚ÄúMy Applications‚Äù
- Click the ‚ÄúApprove More Applications‚Äù button.
- Search for "NASA GESDISC DATA ARCHIVE‚Äù
- Approve that application.
- Wait 5 minutes.
- Try to do all the stuff you did that led you to the authentication loop again.
Hopefully this changes something! Please let me know.
Sincerely,
Nathan
